pauri_punjabi:
ੴ ਸਤਿ ਨਾਮੁ ਕਰਤਾ ਪੁਰਖੁ ਨਿਰਭਉ ਨਿਰਵੈਰੁ
ਅਕਾਲ ਮੂਰਤਿ ਅਜੂਨੀ ਸੈਭੰ ਗੁਰ ਪ੍ਰਸਾਦਿ ॥
transliteration:
Ik Oankaar Sat Naam Karta Purakh Nirbhau Nirvair
Akaal Moorat Ajooni Saibhang Gur Prasaad.
translation:
There is One Universal Creator. His Name is Truth. He is the Creator, without fear, without hate,
Timeless is His form, beyond birth and death, self-existent, known by the Guru’s Grace.
explanation: This is the Mool Mantar, the fundamental creed of Sikhism, encapsulating the core attributes of the Divine. 'Ik Oankaar' signifies the Oneness of God. 'Sat Naam' means His Name is Truth. 'Karta Purakh' identifies Him as the Creator Being. 'Nirbhau Nirvair' describes Him as without fear and without enmity. 'Akaal Moorat' refers to His timeless form, beyond the cycles of time. 'Ajooni Saibhang' means unborn and self-existent. 'Gur Prasaad' indicates that He is realized through the Guru's Grace. This mantra is the essence of Sikh theology, emphasizing the singular, eternal, and benevolent nature of God.

pauri_punjabi:
ਜਪੁ ॥
ਆਦਿ ਸਚੁ ਜੁਗਾਦਿ ਸਚੁ ॥
ਹੈ ਭੀ ਸਚੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਹੋਸੀ ਭੀ ਸਚੁ ॥੧॥
transliteration:
Jap.
Aad Sach Jugaad Sach.
Hai Bhee Sach Naanak Hosee Bhee Sach. ||1||
translation:
Chant and meditate:
True in the beginning, True throughout the ages,
True even now, O Nanak, He will be True in the future. ||1||
explanation: This is the opening verse of Japji, following the Mool Mantar. It declares the eternal and unchanging nature of Truth (God). It states that God was true from the very beginning, true throughout all ages, is true in the present, and will remain true in the future. This emphasizes the timelessness and absolute reality of the Divine, setting the foundation for the entire composition.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸੋਚੈ ਸੋਚਿ ਨ ਹੋਵਈ ਜੇ ਸੋਚੀ ਲਖ ਵਾਰ ॥
ਚੁਪੈ ਚੁਪ ਨ ਹੋਵਈ ਜੇ ਲਾਇ ਰਹਾ ਲਿਵ ਤਾਰ ॥
ਭੁਖਿਆ ਭੁਖ ਨ ਉਤਰੀ ਜੇ ਬੰਨਾ ਪੁਰੀਆ ਭਾਰ ॥
ਸਹਸ ਸਿਆਣਪਾ ਲਖ ਹੋਹਿ ਤ ਇਕ ਨ ਚਲੈ ਨਾਲਿ ॥
ਕਿਵ ਸਚਿਆਰਾ ਹੋਈਐ ਕਿਵ ਕੂੜੈ ਤੁਟੈ ਪਾਲਿ ॥
ਹੁਕਮਿ ਰਜਾਈ ਚਲਣਾ ਨਾਨਕ ਲਿਖਿਆ ਨਾਲਿ ॥੧॥
transliteration:
Sochai Soch na hovai je sochi lakh vaar.
Chupai chup na hovai je laae rahaa liv taar.
Bhukhi-aa bhukh na utree je bannaa puree-aa bhaar.
Sahas si-aanpaa lakh hohi ta ik na chalai naal.
Kiv sachi-aaraa ho-ee-ai kiv koorhai tutai paal.
Hukam rajaa-ee chalnaa Naanak likhi-aa naal. ||1||
translation:
By thinking, He cannot be reduced to thought, even by thinking hundreds of thousands of times.
By remaining silent, inner silence is not obtained, even by remaining lovingly absorbed deep within.
The hunger of the hungry is not appeased, even by piling up loads of worldly goods.
Hundreds of thousands of clever tricks, but not even one of them will go along with you in the end.
So, how can you become truthful? And how can the veil of illusion be torn away?
O Nanak, it is written that you shall obey the Hukam of His Command, and walk in the Way of His Will. ||1||
explanation: This verse teaches that true understanding of God and inner purity cannot be achieved through external rituals or intellectual pursuits alone. It rejects the efficacy of mere thought, forced silence, material accumulation, or worldly cleverness in realizing the Divine. It poses a fundamental question: how can one become truthful and break the wall of falsehood? The answer is profound: by accepting and living according to God's 'Hukam' (Divine Will or Command). This sets the central theme of Japji Sahib, emphasizing surrender to the Divine Order.

pauri_punjabi:
ਹੁਕਮੀ ਹੋਵਨਿ ਆਕਾਰ ਹੁਕਮੁ ਨ ਕਹਿਆ ਜਾਈ ॥
ਹੁਕਮੀ ਹੋਵਨਿ ਜੀਅ ਹੁਕਮਿ ਮਿਲੈ ਵਡਿਆਈ ॥
ਹੁਕਮੀ ਉਤਮੁ ਨੀਚੁ ਹੁਕਮਿ ਲਿਖਿ ਦੁਖ ਸੁਖ ਪਾਈਅਹਿ ॥
ਇਕਨਾ ਹੁਕਮੀ ਬਖਸੀਸ ਇਕਿ ਹੁਕਮੀ ਸਦਾ ਭਵਾਈਅਹਿ ॥
ਹੁਕਮੈ ਅੰਦਰਿ ਸਭੁ ਕੋ ਬਾਹਰਿ ਹੁਕਮ ਨ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਹੁਕਮੈ ਜੇ ਬੁਝੈ ਤ ਹਉਮੈ ਕਹੈ ਨ ਕੋਇ ॥੨॥
transliteration:
Hukmee hovan aakaar hukam na kahi-aa jaa-ee.
Hukmee hovan jee-a hukam milai vadi-aa-ee.
Hukmee utam neech hukam likh dukh sukh paa-ee-ah.
Iknaa hukmee bakhsees ik hukmee sadaa bhavaa-ee-ah.
Hukmai andar sabh ko baahar hukam na ko-e.
Naanak hukmai je bujhai ta ha-umai kahai na ko-e. ||2||
translation:
By His Command, bodies are created; His Command cannot be described.
By His Command, souls come into being; by His Command, greatness is obtained.
By His Command, some are high and some are low; by His Command, pain and pleasure are inscribed.
By His Command, some are blessed with forgiveness; by His Command, others are made to wander forever.
Everyone is subject to His Command; no one is outside of His Command.
O Nanak, one who understands His Command, does not speak in ego. ||2||
explanation: This pauri elaborates on the concept of 'Hukam' (Divine Will). It states that everything in creation, from the formation of bodies to the existence of souls, and the distribution of joy and sorrow, is by God's Command. It emphasizes that 'Hukam' is all-encompassing – no one is outside its purview. The understanding and acceptance of 'Hukam' lead to the dissolution of ego ('haumai'), as one realizes that all is by Divine Will, leaving no room for personal pride or claims of self-agency. This brings humility and a deeper connection with the Creator.

pauri_punjabi:
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਤਾਣੁ ਹੋਵੈ ਕਿਸੈ ਤਾਣੁ ॥
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਦਾਤਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਨੀਸਾਣੁ ॥
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਗੁਣ ਵਡਿਆਈਆ ਚਾਰ ॥
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਵਿਦਿਆ ਵਿਖਮ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਸਾਜਿ ਕਰੇ ਤਨੁ ਖੇਹ ॥
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਜੀਅ ਲੈ ਫਿਰਿ ਦੇਹ ॥
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਜਾਪੈ ਦਿਸੈ ਦੂਰਿ ॥
ਗਾਵੈ ਕੋ ਵੇਖੈ ਹਾਦਰਾ ਹਦੂਰਿ ॥
ਕਥਨਾ ਕਥੀ ਨ ਆਵੈ ਤੋਟਿ ॥
ਕਥਿ ਕਥਿ ਕਥੀ ਕੋਟੀ ਕੋਟਿ ਕੋਟਿ ॥
ਦੇਦਾ ਦੇ ਲੈਦੇ ਥਕਿ ਪਾਹਿ ॥
ਜੁਗਾ ਜੁਗੰਤਰਿ ਖਾਹੀ ਖਾਹਿ ॥
ਹੁਕਮੀ ਹੁਕਮੁ ਚਲਾਏ ਰਾਹੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਵਿਗਸੈ ਵੇਪਰਵਾਹੁ ॥੩॥
transliteration:
Gaavai ko taan hovai kisai taan.
Gaavai ko daat jaanai neesaan.
Gaavai ko gun vadi-aa-ee-aa chaar.
Gaavai ko vidi-aa vikham veechaar.
Gaavai ko saaj kare tan kheh.
Gaavai ko jee-a lai fir deh.
Gaavai ko jaapai disai door.
Gaavai ko vekhai haadraa hadoor.
Kathnaa kathee na aavai tot.
Kath kath kathee kotee kot kot.
Deydaa de laide thak paahi.
Jugaa jugantar khaahee khaahi.
Hukmee hukam chalaae raahu.
Naanak vigsai veparvaahu. ||3||
translation:
Some sing of His power, if they have the power to do so.
Some sing of His gifts, recognizing His signs.
Some sing of His glorious, beautiful attributes.
Some sing of His wisdom, and of difficult spiritual reflections.
Some sing that He creates the body and then reduces it to dust.
Some sing that He takes life away, and then gives it back again.
Some sing that He seems so far away.
Some sing that He watches, ever-present, close at hand.
The tellers tell, but their telling does not come to an end.
The speakers speak, millions upon millions of them.
The Great Giver keeps on giving, while the receivers grow weary of receiving.
Throughout the ages, consumers consume.
By His Command, the Commander walks on His Way.
O Nanak, He blossoms forth, free of all care. ||3||
explanation: This pauri highlights the diverse ways in which people try to comprehend and describe God, yet ultimately fail to fully grasp His infinite nature. It lists various aspects people focus on – His power, gifts, attributes, wisdom, ability to create and destroy, and His perceived distance or closeness. Despite countless attempts to describe Him, His virtues and generosity are inexhaustible. The core message reiterates that God acts by His own 'Hukam,' untroubled and boundless, emphasizing His independent and sovereign nature. Human efforts to define Him are always limited.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸਾਚਾ ਸਾਹਿਬੁ ਸਾਚੁ ਨਾਇ ਭਾਖਿਆ ਭਾਉ ਅਪਾਰੁ ॥
ਆਖਹਿ ਮੰਗਹਿ ਦੇਹਿ ਦੇਹਿ ਦਾਤਿ ਕਰੇ ਦਾਤਾਰੁ ॥
ਫੇਰਿ ਕਿ ਅਗੈ ਰਖੀਐ ਜਿਤੁ ਦਿਸੈ ਦਰਬਾਰੁ ॥
ਮੁਹੌ ਕਿ ਬੋਲਣੁ ਬੋਲੀਐ ਜਿਤੁ ਸੁਣਿ ਧਰੇ ਪਿਆਰੁ ॥
ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤ ਵੇਲਾ ਸਚੁ ਨਾਉ ਵਡਿਆਈ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਕਰਮੀ ਆਵੈ ਕਪੜਾ ਨਦਰੀ ਮੋਖੁ ਦੁਆਰੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਏਵੈ ਜਾਣੀਐ ਸਭੁ ਆਪੇ ਸਚਿਆਰੁ ॥੪॥
transliteration:
Saachaa Saahib Saach Naae Bhaakhi-aa Bha-o Apaar.
Aakhahi Mangahi Dehi Dehi Daat Kare Daataar.
Pher ki agai rakhi-ai jit disai darbaar.
Muho ki bolan bolee-ai jit sun dhare pi-aar.
Amrit Vela Sach Naa-o Vadi-aa-ee Veechaar.
Karmee aavai kapraa nadree mokh du-aar.
Naanak evai jaanee-ai sabh aape sachi-aar. ||4||
translation:
The True Lord, True is His Name; His language is boundless love.
People pray and beg, 'Give, give,' and the Great Giver grants His gifts.
So what offering can we place before Him, by which we might see His Darbar, His Court?
What words can we speak with our mouths, which would inspire Him to lovingly listen?
In the Amrit Vaylā, the ambrosial hours of the morning, chant the True Name, and contemplate His Glorious Greatness.
By the karma of past actions, the robe of this human body is obtained; by His Grace, the Door of Liberation is found.
O Nanak, know that the True One Himself is All. ||4||
explanation: This pauri begins by affirming God as the True Master whose Name is Truth and whose essence is boundless love. It acknowledges humanity's constant asking for gifts from this Great Giver. It then poses a crucial question: how can we truly connect with Him and receive His love? The answer is to meditate on the True Name ('Sach Naao') and contemplate His greatness during 'Amrit Vela' (the ambrosial hours before dawn). It also introduces the concept that the human birth ('kapraa') is a result of past karma, but liberation ('mokh du-aar') is attained only through God's Grace ('Nadree'). The verse concludes by emphasizing that God Himself is the ultimate Truth and Reality.

pauri_punjabi:
ਥਾਪਿਆ ਨ ਜਾਇ ਕੀਤਾ ਨ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਆਪੇ ਆਪਿ ਨਿਰੰਜਨੁ ਸੋਇ ॥
ਜਿਨਿ ਸੇਵਿਆ ਤਿਨਿ ਪਾਇਆ ਮਾਨੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਗਾਵੀਐ ਗੁਣੀ ਨਿਧਾਨੁ ॥
ਗਾਵੀਐ ਸੁਣੀਐ ਮਨਿ ਰਖੀਐ ਭਾਉ ॥
ਦੁਖੁ ਪਰਹਰਿ ਸੁਖੁ ਘਰਿ ਲੈ ਜਾਇ ॥
ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਨਾਦੰ ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਵੇਦੰ ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਰਹਿਆ ਸਮਾਈ ॥
ਗੁਰ ਈਸਰੁ ਗੁਰੁ ਗੋਰਖੁ ਬਰਮਾ ਗੁਰੁ ਪਾਰਬਤੀ ਮਾਈ ॥
ਜੇ ਹਉ ਜਾਣਾ ਆਖਾ ਨਾਹੀ ਕਹਣਾ ਕਥਨੁ ਨ ਜਾਈ ॥
ਗੁਰਾ ਇਕ ਦੇਹਿ ਬੁਝਾਈ ॥
ਸਭਨਾ ਜੀਆ ਕਾ ਇਕੁ ਦਾਤਾ ਸੋ ਮੈ ਵਿਸਰਿ ਨ ਜਾਈ ॥੫॥
transliteration:
Thaapi-aa na jaae keetaa na ho-e.
Aape Aap niranjan so-e.
Jin sevi-aa tin paa-i-aa maan.
Naanak gaavee-ai Gunee Nidhaan.
Gaavee-ai sunee-ai man rakhee-ai bha-o.
Dukh parhar sukh ghar lai jaae.
Gurmukh naadang Gurmukh vedang Gurmukh rahi-aa samaa-ee.
Gur Eesar Gur Gorakh Barmaa Gur Paarvatee Maa-ee.
Je ha-o jaanaa aakhaa naahee kahnaa kathan na jaa-ee.
Guraa ik dehi bujhaa-ee.
Sabhnaa jee-aa kaa ik daataa so mai visar na jaa-ee. ||5||
translation:
He cannot be established, nor can He be created.
He Himself is the Immaculate One.
Whoever serves Him, obtains honor.
O Nanak, sing of the Lord, the Treasure of Virtue.
Sing, and listen, and keep His love in your mind.
Sorrow shall be dispelled, and peace shall come to your home.
The Gurmukh (Guru-oriented) understands the spiritual sound current; the Gurmukh understands the Vedas; the Gurmukh understands that God is pervading everywhere.
The Guru is Shiva, the Guru is Gorakh, Brahma, and the Divine Mother Paarvati.
Even if I knew, I could not describe it; it cannot be described in words.
The Guru has blessed me with this one understanding:
There is only One Giver to all beings; may I never forget Him. ||5||
explanation: This pauri states that God is not created or established by anyone; He is self-existent and pure. It emphasizes that those who serve Him gain honor. The core teaching is to sing praises of God, listen to His Word, and keep His love in the heart, which leads to the removal of sorrow and the attainment of peace. It then extols the role of the Guru, defining the 'Gurmukh' (one who follows the Guru) as capable of understanding spiritual truths and the pervasive nature of God. The Guru is equated with various deities (Shiva, Gorakh, Brahma, Paarvati) not to imply polytheism, but to highlight the Guru's supreme spiritual authority and guidance, encompassing all aspects of divine wisdom. The pauri concludes with Guru Nanak's profound realization: even if one knew, God's greatness cannot be fully described. The ultimate understanding given by the Guru is that there is only One Giver for all beings, and this truth should never be forgotten.

pauri_punjabi:
ਤੀਰਥਿ ਨਾਵਾ ਜੇ ਤਿਸੁ ਭਾਵਾ ਵਿਣੁ ਭਾਣੇ ਕਿ ਨਾਇ ਕਰੀ ॥
ਜੇਤੀ ਸਿਰਠਿ ਉਪਾਈ ਵੇਖਾ ਵਿਣੁ ਕਰਮਾ ਕਿ ਮਿਲੈ ਲਈ ॥
ਮਤਿ ਵਿਚਿ ਰਤਨ ਜਵਾਹਰ ਮਾਣਿਕ ਜੇ ਇਕ ਗੁਰ ਕੀ ਸਿਖ ਸੁਣੀ ॥
ਗੁਰਾ ਇਕ ਦੇਹਿ ਬੁਝਾਈ ॥
ਸਭਨਾ ਜੀਆ ਕਾ ਇਕੁ ਦਾਤਾ ਸੋ ਮੈ ਵਿਸਰਿ ਨ ਜਾਈ ॥੬॥
transliteration:
Teerath naavaa je tis bhaavaa vin bhaane ki naae karee.
Jetee sirath upaa-ee vekhaa vin karmaa ki milai la-ee.
Mat vich ratan javaahar maanik je ik Gur kee sikh sunee.
Guraa ik dehi bujhaa-ee.
Sabhnaa jee-aa kaa ik daataa so mai visar na jaa-ee. ||6||
translation:
I would bathe at sacred shrines, if it pleased Him; otherwise, what good is ritual bathing?
As many beings as I behold created, I see that without good deeds, what can one receive?
Within the intellect are jewels, gems, and rubies, if one listens to the Guru’s teaching.
The Guru has blessed me with this one understanding:
There is only One Giver to all beings; may I never forget Him. ||6||
explanation: This pauri continues the theme of external rituals being secondary to divine grace and understanding. It questions the efficacy of pilgrimage (bathing at sacred shrines) if it does not align with God's will. It also asserts that worldly attainments are a result of one's actions ('karma'). However, the true treasures – spiritual jewels, gems, and rubies (wisdom, enlightenment) – are found within the intellect when one sincerely listens to and follows the Guru's teachings ('Gur kee sikh'). The concluding lines, repeated from the previous pauri, reinforce the central revelation received from the Guru: the singularity of the Divine Giver and the importance of never forgetting this truth.

pauri_punjabi:
ਜੇ ਜੁਗ ਚਾਰੇ ਆਰਜਾ ਹੋਰ ਦਸੂਣੀ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਨਵਾ ਖੰਡਾ ਵਿਚਿ ਜਾਣੀਐ ਨਾਲਿ ਚਲੈ ਸਭੁ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਚੰਗਾ ਨਾਉ ਰਖਾਇ ਕੈ ਜਸੁ ਕੀਰਤਿ ਜਗਿ ਲੇਇ ॥
ਜੇ ਤਿਸੁ ਨਦਰਿ ਨ ਆਵਈ ਤ ਵਾਤ ਨ ਪੁਛੈ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਕੀਟਾ ਅੰਦਰਿ ਕੀਟੁ ਕਰਿ ਦੋਸੀ ਦੋਸੁ ਧਰੇ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਨਿਰਗੁਣਿ ਗੁਣੁ ਕਰੇ ਗੁਣਵੰਤਿਆ ਗੁਣੁ ਦੇ ॥
ਤੇਹਾ ਕੋਇ ਨ ਸੁਝਈ ਜਿ ਤਿਸੁ ਗੁਣੁ ਕੋਇ ਕਰੇ ॥੭॥
transliteration:
Je jug chaare aarjā hor dasoonee ho-e.
Navaa Khandaa vich jaanee-ai naal chalai sabh ko-e.
Changaa Naao rakhaa-e kai jas keerat jag le-e.
Je tis nadar na aava-ee ta vaat na puchhai ko-e.
Keetaa andar keet kar dose dos dhare.
Naanak nirgun gun kare gunvantee-aa gun de.
Tehaa ko-e na sujh-ee je tis gun ko-e kare. ||7||
translation:
Even if one were to live through the four ages, or even ten times longer,
And be known throughout the nine continents, with everyone following in their wake;
And earn a good name, and gain fame and praise throughout the world;
If He does not cast His Glance of Grace, then no one would care to ask about them.
He makes worms out of worms, and makes the sinner sinful.
O Nanak, He blesses the worthless with worth, and gives virtue to the virtuous.
No one can be found who can bestow virtue upon Him. ||7||
explanation: This pauri emphasizes that worldly achievements, longevity, fame, and popularity are ultimately meaningless without God's Grace ('Nadar'). Even if one lives for eons, is known worldwide, and earns immense respect, if God does not cast His gracious glance, all such accomplishments are futile. It highlights God's absolute sovereignty and His ability to transform even the most worthless into virtuous beings, and to further empower the virtuous. The verse concludes by stating that no one can bestow any virtue upon God, affirming His absolute perfection and self-sufficiency. All goodness originates from Him.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਸਿਧ ਪੀਰ ਸੁਰਿ ਨਾਥ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਧਰਤਿ ਧਵਲ ਆਕਾਸ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਦੀਪ ਲੋਅ ਪਾਤਾਲ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਪੋਹਿ ਨ ਸਕੈ ਕਾਲੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਭਗਤਾ ਸਦਾ ਵਿਗਾਸੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਦੂਖ ਪਾਪ ਕਾ ਨਾਸੁ ॥੮॥
transliteration:
Suni-ai sidh peer suri naath.
Suni-ai dharat dhaval aakaas.
Suni-ai deep lo-a paataal.
Suni-ai pohi na sakai kaal.
Naanak bhagtaa sadaa vigaas.
Suni-ai dookh paap kaa naas. ||8||
translation:
By listening, one becomes a Siddha, a Pir, a spiritual hero, a master.
By listening, one comprehends the earth, its supporting forces, and the ethers.
By listening, one comprehends the continents, the worlds, and the nether regions.
By listening, the fear of death cannot touch you.
O Nanak, the devotees are forever in bliss.
By listening, suffering and sin are erased. ||8||
explanation: This pauri begins a series of verses (Pauris 8-11) praising the power and benefits of 'Sunna' (listening to or heeding the Divine Word/Name). It states that by listening, one can attain the spiritual status of Siddhas (perfected ones), Pirs (Muslim saints), and spiritual masters. Listening brings understanding of the vast universe – earth, sky, continents, and nether regions. Crucially, it liberates one from the fear of death. For devotees, listening brings perpetual bliss, and it leads to the destruction of suffering and sin. This emphasizes the transformative power of internalizing the Divine Message.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਈਸਰੁ ਬਰਮਾ ਇੰਦੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਮੁਖਿ ਸਾਲਾਹਣ ਮੰਦੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਜੋਗ ਜੁਗਤਿ ਤਨਿ ਭੇਦ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਸਾਸਤ ਸਿੰਮ੍ਰਿਤਿ ਵੇਦ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਭਗਤਾ ਸਦਾ ਵਿਗਾਸੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਦੂਖ ਪਾਪ ਕਾ ਨਾਸੁ ॥੯॥
transliteration:
Suni-ai Eesar Barmaa Ind.
Suni-ai mukh saalaahan mand.
Suni-ai jog jugat tan bhed.
Suni-ai saasat simrit ved.
Naanak bhagtaa sadaa vigaas.
Suni-ai dookh paap kaa naas. ||9||
translation:
By listening, one understands Shiva, Brahma, and Indra.
By listening, even the mouth of the slanderer praises God.
By listening, one understands the ways of Yoga and the secrets of the body.
By listening, one understands the Shastras, the Simritees, and the Vedas.
O Nanak, the devotees are forever in bliss.
By listening, suffering and sin are erased. ||9||
explanation: Continuing the theme of 'Sunna', this pauri further details the benefits of listening to the Divine Word. It asserts that by listening, one can comprehend the nature of deities like Shiva, Brahma, and Indra (representing different aspects of creation, preservation, and destruction in Hindu mythology). It has the power to transform even a slanderer into a praiser of God. Listening also reveals the secrets of Yoga and the mysteries of the human body, as well as the wisdom contained in various religious scriptures like the Shastras, Smritis, and Vedas. The repeated concluding lines reiterate the profound outcome: devotees find eternal bliss, and suffering and sin are eradicated through this profound act of listening and internalizing.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਸਤੁ ਸੰਤੋਖੁ ਗਿਆਨੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਅਠਸਠਿ ਕਾ ਇਸਨਾਨੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਪੜਿ ਪੜਿ ਪਾਵਹਿ ਮਾਨੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਲਾਗੈ ਸਹਜਿ ਧਿਆਨੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਭਗਤਾ ਸਦਾ ਵਿਗਾਸੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਦੂਖ ਪਾਪ ਕਾ ਨਾਸੁ ॥੧੦॥
transliteration:
Suni-ai sat santokh gi-aan.
Suni-ai athsath kaa isnaan.
Suni-ai parh parh paavahi maan.
Suni-ai laagai sahaj dhi-aan.
Naanak bhagtaa sadaa vigaas.
Suni-ai dookh paap kaa naas. ||10||
translation:
By listening, one gains truth, contentment, and spiritual wisdom.
By listening, one obtains the merit of bathing at the sixty-eight sacred shrines.
By listening, scholars achieve honor through their studies.
By listening, one spontaneously enters into deep meditation.
O Nanak, the devotees are forever in bliss.
By listening, suffering and sin are erased. ||10||
explanation: This pauri continues the glorification of 'Sunna' (listening to the Divine Word). It states that through listening, one cultivates virtues like **truthfulness (sat)**, **contentment (santokh)**, and **spiritual knowledge (giaan)**. It metaphorically suggests that the spiritual purification achieved by listening is equivalent to the merit of bathing at all sixty-eight sacred pilgrimage sites, emphasizing the internal purity over external rituals. Furthermore, listening brings honor to scholars and naturally leads to **spontaneous meditation (sahaj dhiaan)**. The concluding lines, a refrain in these pauris, reaffirm that listening brings perpetual bliss to devotees and eradicates sorrow and sin.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਸਰਾ ਗੁਣਾ ਕੇ ਗਾਹ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਸੇਖ ਪੀਰ ਪਾਤਿਸਾਹ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਅੰਧੇ ਪਾਵਹਿ ਰਾਹੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਹਾਥ ਹੋਵੈ ਅਸਗਾਹੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਭਗਤਾ ਸਦਾ ਵਿਗਾਸੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਐ ਦੂਖ ਪਾਪ ਕਾ ਨਾਸੁ ॥੧੧॥
transliteration:
Suni-ai saraa gunaa ke gaah.
Suni-ai sekh peer paatisaah.
Suni-ai andhe paavahi raahu.
Suni-ai haath hovai asgaahu.
Naanak bhagtaa sadaa vigaas.
Suni-ai dookh paap kaa naas. ||11||
translation:
By listening, one plunges into the ocean of virtues.
By listening, one becomes a Sheikh, a Pir, or a King.
By listening, the blind find the path.
By listening, the unfathomable becomes fathomable in one's hands.
O Nanak, the devotees are forever in bliss.
By listening, suffering and sin are erased. ||11||
explanation: This is the final pauri in the series on 'Sunna'. It portrays listening as a means to dive into the **ocean of virtues**. It suggests that through sincere listening, one can attain high spiritual and worldly status, becoming like a **Sheikh, Pir, or even a King** (implying spiritual sovereignty). Crucially, it highlights the power of listening to guide the 'blind' (spiritually ignorant) onto the right path and to make the seemingly **unfathomable (God's mysteries)** accessible and understandable. The repeated concluding lines stress the continuous bliss for devotees and the eradication of sorrow and sin through this profound act of listening.

pauri_punjabi:
ਮੰਨੈ ਕੀ ਗਤਿ ਕਹੀ ਨ ਜਾਇ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਕਹੈ ਤ ਪਿਛੈ ਪਛੁਤਾਇ ॥
ਕਾਗਦਿ ਕਲਮ ਨ ਲਿਖਣਹਾਰੁ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਕਾ ਬਹਿ ਕਰਹਿ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਐਸਾ ਨਾਮੁ ਨਿਰੰਜਨੁ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਮੰਨਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਮਨਿ ਕੋਇ ॥੧੨॥
transliteration:
Mannai kee gat kahee na jaae.
Je ko kahai ta pichhai pachhutaa-e.
Kaagad kalam na likhanhaar.
Mannai kaa bahi karahi veechaar.
Aisaa naam niranjan ho-e.
Je ko man jaanai man ko-e. ||12||
translation:
The state of the faithful cannot be described.
Even if someone tries to describe it, they will later regret it.
No paper, no pen, no scribe
Can describe the state of the faithful.
Such is the Immaculate Name.
If one believes and knows it in their mind. ||12||
explanation: This pauri introduces the concept of 'Mannai' (faith, acceptance, or believing in the Divine Word). It emphasizes that the **spiritual state of a faithful person is ineffable**; it cannot be truly described or fully grasped through words. Attempts to articulate it are futile and will lead to regret. No human means—neither paper, pen, nor scribe—can capture its essence. The Name of the Immaculate Lord is of such profound nature that its power is realized only when one truly **accepts and embodies it within the mind**. This shift from 'listening' to 'believing/accepting' signifies a deeper level of spiritual engagement.

pauri_punjabi:
ਮੰਨੈ ਸੁਰਤਿ ਹੋਵੈ ਮਨਿ ਬੁਧਿ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਸਗਲ ਭਵਣ ਕੀ ਸੁਧਿ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਮੁਹਿ ਚੋਟਾ ਨਾ ਖਾਇ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਜਮ ਕੈ ਸਾਥਿ ਨ ਜਾਇ ॥
ਐਸਾ ਨਾਮੁ ਨਿਰੰਜਨੁ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਮੰਨਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਮਨਿ ਕੋਇ ॥੧੩॥
transliteration:
Mannai surat hovai man budh.
Mannai sagal bhavan kee sudh.
Mannai muh chotaa naa khaa-e.
Mannai jam kai saath na jaae.
Aisaa Naam Niranjan ho-e.
Je ko man jaanai man ko-e. ||13||
translation:
By believing, understanding and intelligence are attained in the mind.
By believing, one gains knowledge of all worlds.
By believing, one does not suffer blows to the face (disgrace).
By believing, one does not go along with the Messenger of Death.
Such is the Immaculate Name.
If one believes and knows it in their mind. ||13||
explanation: This pauri continues to delineate the benefits of 'Mannai'. It states that through unwavering faith, one gains **spiritual awareness (surat)**, **mental clarity**, and **intellectual understanding (budh)**. This leads to a comprehensive awareness of all realms and existence. A faithful person is protected from **disgrace (muh chotaa)** in this world and, more importantly, from the **clutches of death (Jam)** and the cycle of rebirth. The concluding lines, repeated from the previous pauri, emphasize that this profound power resides in the Immaculate Name, accessible to those who truly believe and internalize it.

pauri_punjabi:
ਮੰਨੈ ਮਾਰਗਿ ਠਾਕ ਨ ਪਾਇ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਪਤਿ ਸਿਉ ਪਰਗਟੁ ਜਾਇ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਮਗੁ ਨ ਚਲੈ ਪੰਥੁ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਧਰਮ ਸੇਤੀ ਸਨਬੰਧੁ ॥
ਐਸਾ ਨਾਮੁ ਨਿਰੰਜਨੁ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਮੰਨਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਮਨਿ ਕੋਇ ॥੧੪॥
transliteration:
Mannai maarag thaak na paae.
Mannai pat si-o pargat jaae.
Mannai mag na chalai panth.
Mannai dharam setee sanbandh.
Aisaa Naam Niranjan ho-e.
Je ko man jaanai man ko-e. ||14||
translation:
By believing, one's path is not obstructed.
By believing, one goes forth with honor and renown.
By believing, one follows no particular path or sect (but the true path).
By believing, one connects with righteousness and Dharma.
Such is the Immaculate Name.
If one believes and knows it in their mind. ||14||
explanation: This pauri highlights the practical and spiritual benefits of 'Mannai' on one's life path. It states that true faith removes obstacles from one's spiritual journey, allowing them to proceed with **honor and dignity**. It implies that those with 'Mannai' are not bound by rigid sectarian paths but rather find the universal 'true path'. Furthermore, believing connects one deeply with **righteousness (Dharam)** and moral conduct. The recurring refrain reiterates that the Immaculate Name holds this power, accessible only to those who truly believe and internalize it in their hearts.

pauri_punjabi:
ਮੰਨੈ ਪਾਵਹਿ ਮੋਖੁ ਦੁਆਰੁ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਪਰਵਾਰੈ ਸਾਧਾਰੁ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਤਰੈ ਤਾਰੇ ਗੁਰੁ ਸਿਖ ॥
ਮੰਨੈ ਨਾਨਕ ਭਵਹਿ ਨ ਭਿਖ ॥
ਐਸਾ ਨਾਮੁ ਨਿਰੰਜਨੁ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਮੰਨਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਮਨਿ ਕੋਇ ॥੧੫॥
transliteration:
Mannai paavahi mokh du-aar.
Mannai parvaarai saadhaar.
Mannai tarai taare Gur sikh.
Mannai Naanak bhavahi na bhikh.
Aisaa Naam Niranjan ho-e.
Je ko man jaanai man ko-e. ||15||
translation:
By believing, one finds the Gate of Liberation.
By believing, one's family is also saved.
By believing, the Guru's disciple is saved, and saves others.
O Nanak, by believing, one does not wander as a beggar.
Such is the Immaculate Name.
If one believes and knows it in their mind. ||15||
explanation: This pauri concludes the 'Mannai' series by outlining its ultimate spiritual rewards. It states that true faith leads to the **Door of Liberation (Mokh Du-aar)**, freeing one from the cycle of rebirth. The power of 'Mannai' extends beyond the individual, as it becomes a means of **support for one's family**, implying spiritual upliftment for them. A Guru's disciple who believes not only saves themselves but also **helps others cross the ocean of existence**. Finally, through faith, one escapes the need to 'beg' spiritually or materially, finding inner fulfillment. The recurring refrain underscores that this transformative power resides in the Immaculate Name for those who truly believe.

pauri_punjabi:
ਪੰਚ ਪਰਵਾਣ ਪੰਚ ਪਰਧਾਨੁ ॥
ਪੰਚੇ ਪਾਵਹਿ ਦਰਗਹਿ ਮਾਨੁ ॥
ਪੰਚੇ ਸੋਹਹਿ ਦਰਿ ਰਾਜਾਨੁ ॥
ਪੰਚਾ ਕਾ ਗੁਰੁ ਏਕੁ ਧਿਆਨੁ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਕਹੈ ਕਰੈ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਕਰਤੇ ਕੈ ਕਰਣੈ ਨਾਹੀ ਸੁਮਾਰੁ ॥
ਧੌਲੁ ਧਰਮੁ ਦਇਆ ਕਾ ਪੂਤੁ ॥
ਸੰਤੋਖੁ ਥਾਪਿ ਰਖਿਆ ਜਿਨਿ ਸੂਤਿ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਬੁਝੈ ਹੋਵੈ ਸਚਿਆਰੁ ॥
ਧਵਲੈ ਉਪਰਿ ਕੇਤਾ ਭਾਰੁ ॥
ਧਰਤੀ ਹੋਰੁ ਪਰੈ ਹੋਰੁ ਹੋਰੁ ॥
ਤਿਸੁ ਭਾਰੁ ਤਲੈ ਕਵਣੁ ਜੋਰੁ ॥
ਜੀਅ ਜਾਤਿ ਰੰਗਾ ਕੇ ਨਾਵ ॥
ਸਭਨਾ ਲਿਖਿਆ ਵੁੜੀ ਕਲਾਮ ॥
ਏਹੁ ਲੇਖਾ ਲਿਖਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਤਾ ਲੇਖਾ ਲਿਖਿਆ ਕੇਤਾ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਕੇਤਾ ਤਾਣੁ ਸੁਆਲਿਹੁ ਰੂਪੁ ॥
ਕੇਤੀ ਦਾਤਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਕਉਣੁ ਕੂਤੁ ॥
ਕੀਤਾ ਪਸਾਉ ਏਕੋ ਕਵਾਉ ॥
ਤਿਸ ਤੇ ਹੋਏ ਲਖ ਦਰੀਆਉ ॥
ਕੁਦਰਤਿ ਕਵਣ ਕਹਾ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਵਾਰਿਆ ਨ ਜਾਵਾ ਏਕ ਵਾਰ ॥
ਜੋ ਤੁਧੁ ਭਾਵੈ ਸਾਈ ਭਲੀ ਕਾਰ ॥
ਤੂ ਸਦਾ ਸਲਾਮਤਿ ਨਿਰੰਕਾਰ ॥੧੬॥
transliteration:
Panch parvaan panch pardhaan.
Panche paavahi dargah maan.
Panche sohahi dar raajaan.
Panchaa kaa Gur ek dhiaan.
Je ko kahai karai veechaar.
Karte kai karni naahee sumaar.
Dhaul dharam da-i-aa kaa poot.
Santokh thaap rakhi-aa jin soot.
Je ko bujhai hovai sachi-aar.
Dhavlai upar ketaa bhaar.
Dhartee hor parai hor hor.
Tisu bhaar talai kavan jor.
Jee-a jaat rangaa ke naav.
Sabhnaa likhi-aa vurhee kalaam.
Eh lekhaa likh jaanai ko-e.
Taa lekhaa likhi-aa ketaa ho-e.
Ketaa taan su-aalih roop.
Ketee daat jaanai ka-un koot.
Keetaa pasaao eko kavaao.
Tis te ho-e lakh daree-aao.
Kudrat kavan kahaa veechaar.
Vaari-aa na jaavaa ek vaar.
Jo tudh bhaavai saa-ee bhalee kaar.
Too sadaa salaamat Nirankaar. ||16||
translation:
The five accepted ones, the five distinguished ones.
The five attain honor in the Court of the Lord.
The five look beautiful at the King’s Gate.
Their Guru is their one-pointed meditation on God.
Whoever tries to describe and reflect upon it—
The creative power of the Creator is beyond measure.
Righteousness, the son of compassion, is the mythical bull.
By contentment, He established the universe in its place.
If one understands this, they become truthful.
How much weight is on that bull?
There are other earths, and still more beyond.
What power supports the weight beneath them?
There are so many species of beings, of so many colors and names.
All are written by the flowing pen of destiny.
If anyone tries to write this account,
Then how extensive would that account be?
How great is His power, and how beautiful His form?
Who can estimate His gifts?
He created the expansion of the universe with a single Word.
From that, hundreds of thousands of rivers (of life) began to flow.
What power do I have to describe Your wondrous ways?
I cannot even once be a sacrifice to You.
Whatever pleases You, that is the only good deed.
You are forever stable, O Formless Lord! ||16||
explanation: This lengthy pauri marks a significant shift, beginning with the concept of the **'Panch' (the five accepted, distinguished ones)** – referring to spiritually elevated souls who have achieved a state of acceptance and honor in the Divine Court. Their singular focus is on God. The pauri then delves into the **boundless nature of the Creator's power**. It challenges the mythological concept of a bull supporting the Earth, stating that **Dharma (righteousness), born of compassion**, is the true support, held in place by **contentment**. Guru Nanak then expands on the vastness of creation, with countless earths and beings, all brought into existence by God's single command and written by His pen of destiny. He humbly acknowledges his own inability to fully describe God's immense power, beautiful form, and infinite gifts. The pauri concludes by reiterating that **whatever pleases God is the ultimate good deed**, and affirms God's eternal and **Formless (Nirankar)** nature. This pauri emphasizes humility, the vastness of creation, and the supremacy of God's will and power over human comprehension.

pauri_punjabi:
ਅਸੰਖ ਜਪ ਅਸੰਖ ਭਾਉ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਪੂਜਾ ਅਸੰਖ ਤਪ ਤਾਉ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਗਰੰਥ ਮੁਖਿ ਵੇਦ ਪਾਠ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਜੋਗ ਮਨਿ ਰਹਹਿ ਉਦਾਸ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਭਗਤ ਗੁਣ ਗਿਆਨ ਵੀਚਾਰ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਸਤੀ ਅਸੰਖ ਦਾਤਾਰ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਸੂਰ ਮੁਹ ਭਖ ਸਾਰ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਮੋਨਿ ਲਿਵ ਲਾਇ ਤਾਰ ॥
ਕੁਦਰਤਿ ਕਵਣ ਕਹਾ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਵਾਰਿਆ ਨ ਜਾਵਾ ਏਕ ਵਾਰ ॥
ਜੋ ਤੁਧੁ ਭਾਵੈ ਸਾਈ ਭਲੀ ਕਾਰ ॥
ਤੂ ਸਦਾ ਸਲਾਮਤਿ ਨਿਰੰਕਾਰ ॥੧੭॥
transliteration:
Asankh jap asankh bhaa-o.
Asankh poojaa asankh tap taa-o.
Asankh granth mukh ved paath.
Asankh jog man rahahi udaas.
Asankh bhagat gun gi-aan veechaar.
Asankh satee asankh daataar.
Asankh soor muh bhakh saar.
Asankh mon liv laae taar.
Kudrat kavan kahaa veechaar.
Vaari-aa na jaavaa ek vaar.
Jo tudh bhaavai saa-ee bhalee kaar.
Too sadaa salaamat Nirankaar. ||17||
translation:
Countless are those who meditate and chant, countless who love God.
Countless are those who worship, countless who practice austere penances.
Countless are those who read the scriptures and chant the Vedas from their mouths.
Countless are the Yogis whose minds remain detached.
Countless are the devotees who reflect on God’s virtues and wisdom.
Countless are the truly chaste, countless are the givers.
Countless are the brave warriors who face the steel (of battle).
Countless are the silent sages, absorbed in deep meditation.
What power do I have to describe Your wondrous ways?
I cannot even once be a sacrifice to You.
Whatever pleases You, that is the only good deed.
You are forever stable, O Formless Lord! ||17||
explanation: This pauri employs the word **'Asankh' (countless, innumerable)** to highlight the vast diversity of human spiritual and worldly practices, all undertaken in an attempt to connect with the Divine or live a virtuous life. It enumerates various paths: chanting, loving, worshipping, performing austerities, studying scriptures, practicing yoga, engaging in devotion, being chaste, giving charity, being brave warriors, and maintaining silent meditation. Despite this immense variety and number of human efforts, Guru Nanak once again expresses his inability to truly comprehend or describe God's boundless creation and power. The repeated concluding lines emphasize that **God's will is supreme** and He is the **eternal, Formless Lord**, implying that true understanding lies in surrender to His will rather than human efforts to quantify or fully grasp Him.

pauri_punjabi:
ਅਸੰਖ ਮੂਰਖ ਅੰਧ ਘੋਰ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਚੋਰ ਹਰਾਮਖੋਰ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਅਮਰ ਕਰਿ ਜਾਹਿ ਜੋਰ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਗਲਵਢ ਹਤਿਆ ਕਮਾਹਿ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਪਾਪੀ ਪਾਪੁ ਕਰਿ ਜਾਹਿ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਕੂੜਿਆਰ ਕੂੜੇ ਫਿਰਾਹਿ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਮਲੇਛ ਮਲੁ ਭਖਿ ਖਾਹਿ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਨਿੰਦਕ ਸਿਰਿ ਕਰਹਿ ਭਾਰੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕੁ ਨੀਚੁ ਕਹੈ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਵਾਰਿਆ ਨ ਜਾਵਾ ਏਕ ਵਾਰ ॥
ਜੋ ਤੁਧੁ ਭਾਵੈ ਸਾਈ ਭਲੀ ਕਾਰ ॥
ਤੂ ਸਦਾ ਸਲਾਮਤਿ ਨਿਰੰਕਾਰ ॥੧੮॥
transliteration:
Asankh moorakh andh ghor.
Asankh chor haraamkhor.
Asankh amar kar jaahi jor.
Asankh galvadh hati-aa kamaahi.
Asankh paapee paap kar jaahi.
Asankh koorhi-aar koorhe firaahi.
Asankh malechh mal bhakh khaahi.
Asankh nindak sir karahi bhaar.
Naanak neech kahai veechaar.
Vaari-aa na jaavaa ek vaar.
Jo tudh bhaavai saa-ee bhalee kaar.
Too sadaa salaamat Nirankaar. ||18||
translation:
Countless are the utterly foolish and blind.
Countless are the thieves and embezzlers.
Countless are those who establish their authority by force.
Countless are the cut-throats and murderers.
Countless are the sinners who commit sins and depart.
Countless are the liars who wander in falsehood.
Countless are the wretched who consume filth (spiritual impurity).
Countless are the slanderers who carry the burden of their sins on their heads.
Nanak, the humble, offers this reflection.
I cannot even once be a sacrifice to You.
Whatever pleases You, that is the only good deed.
You are forever stable, O Formless Lord! ||18||
explanation: In stark contrast to the previous pauri, this verse uses 'Asankh' to describe the **countless varieties of negative human behaviors and spiritual failings**. It lists those who are foolish and blind (ignorant), thieves, corrupt individuals, those who rule by force, murderers, chronic sinners, liars, spiritually impure persons, and slanderers. This serves to acknowledge the pervasive presence of vice and moral decay in the world. Despite witnessing this darkness, Guru Nanak remains humble and steadfast in his devotion. The repeated concluding lines serve as a powerful affirmation of God's absolute sovereignty and eternal nature, reinforcing that **only His will is truly good**, irrespective of human actions, good or bad. It's a reminder of God's unchanging nature amidst the myriad human states.

pauri_punjabi:
ਅਸੰਖ ਨਾਵ ਅਸੰਖ ਥਾਵ ॥
ਅਗੰਮ ਅਗੰਮ ਅਸੰਖ ਲੋਅ ॥
ਅਸੰਖ ਕਹਹਿ ਸਿਰਿ ਭਾਰੁ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਅਖਰੀ ਨਾਮੁ ਅਖਰੀ ਸਾਲਾਹ ॥
ਅਖਰੀ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਗੀਤ ਗੁਣ ਗਾਹ ॥
ਅਖਰੀ ਲਿਖਣੁ ਬੋਲਣੁ ਬਾਣੁ ॥
ਅਖਰਾ ਸਿਰਿ ਸੰਜੋਗੁ ਵਖਾਣੁ ॥
ਜਿਨਿ ਏਹਿ ਲਿਖੇ ਤਿਸੁ ਸਿਰਿ ਨਾਹਿ ॥
ਜਿਵ ਫੁਰਮਾਏ ਤਿਵ ਤਿਵ ਪਾਹਿ ॥
ਜੇਤਾ ਕੀਤਾ ਤੇਤਾ ਨਾਉ ॥
ਵਿਣੁ ਨਾਵੈ ਨਾਹੀ ਕੋ ਥਾਉ ॥
ਕੁਦਰਤਿ ਕਵਣ ਕਹਾ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਵਾਰਿਆ ਨ ਜਾਵਾ ਏਕ ਵਾਰ ॥
ਜੋ ਤੁਧੁ ਭਾਵੈ ਸਾਈ ਭਲੀ ਕਾਰ ॥
ਤੂ ਸਦਾ ਸਲਾਮਤਿ ਨਿਰੰਕਾਰ ॥੧੯॥
transliteration:
Asankh Naav Asankh Thaav.
Agamm Agamm Asankh Lo-a.
Asankh kahahi sir bhaar ho-e.
Akhree Naam akhree saalaah.
Akhree gi-aan geet gun gaah.
Akhree likhan bolan baan.
Akhraa sir sanjog vakhaan.
Jin eh likhe tis sir naahi.
Jiv furmaa-e tiv tiv paahi.
Jetaa keetaa tetaa Naa-o.
Vin Naavai naahee ko thaa-o.
Kudrat kavan kahaa veechaar.
Vaari-aa na jaavaa ek vaar.
Jo tudh bhaavai saa-ee bhalee kaar.
Too sadaa salaamat Nirankaar. ||19||
translation:
Countless are Your Names, countless Your places.
Unreachable, unreachable, countless Your worlds.
To speak of all of them is to carry a burden on the head.
In letters is the Name, in letters is Your praise.
In letters is wisdom, in letters are songs of Your virtues.
In letters is writing, speaking, and singing.
On the heads of letters (by God's will), is the record of destiny.
He who wrote them has no destiny written upon His Head.
As He commands, so do beings receive.
As vast as Your creation, so vast is Your Name.
Without the Name, there is no place (nothing exists).
What power do I have to describe Your wondrous ways?
I cannot even once be a sacrifice to You.
Whatever pleases You, that is the only good deed.
You are forever stable, O Formless Lord! ||19||
explanation: This pauri highlights the **infinite nature of God's Names, places, and worlds**, emphasizing their incomprehensibility to humans. It acknowledges that all human communication and knowledge, including scripture, wisdom, and destiny, are expressed through **letters and words ('Akhree')**. However, the **Creator Himself is beyond these limitations**; no destiny is written upon Him. Everything occurs according to His command. The verse then states that **God's Name is as vast as His creation**, and that **nothing exists without His Name**. The recurring refrain underscores Guru Nanak's humility and the supremacy of God's will, affirming the **Formless Lord's eternal stability**.

pauri_punjabi:
ਭਰੀਐ ਹਥੁ ਪੈਰੁ ਤਨੁ ਦੇਹ ॥
ਪਾਣੀ ਧੋਤੈ ਉਤਰਸੁ ਖੇਹ ॥
ਮੂਤ ਪਲੀਤੀ ਕਪੜੁ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਦੇ ਸਾਬੂਣੁ ਲਈਐ ਓਹੁ ਧੋਇ ॥
ਭਰੀਐ ਮਤਿ ਪਾਪਾ ਕੈ ਸੰਗਿ ॥
ਓਹੁ ਧੋਪੈ ਨਾਵੈ ਕੈ ਰੰਗਿ ॥
ਪੁੰਨੀ ਪਾਪੀ ਆਖਣੁ ਨਾਹਿ ॥
ਕਰਿ ਕਰਿ ਕਰਣਾ ਲਿਖਿ ਲੈ ਜਾਹੁ ॥
ਆਪੇ ਬੀਜਿ ਆਪੇ ਹੀ ਖਾਹੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਹੁਕਮੀ ਆਵਹੁ ਜਾਹੁ ॥੨੦॥
transliteration:
Bharee-ai hath pair tan deh.
Paanee dhotai utras kheh. Moot paleetee kaparh ho-e.
De saabooN la-ee-ai oh dho-e.
Bharee-ai mat paapaa kai sang.
Oh dhopai Naavai kai rang.
Punnee paapee aakhan naahi.
Kar kar karnaa likh lai jaahu.
Aape beej aape hee khaahu.
Naanak hukmee aavahu jaahu. ||20||
translation:
When the hands, feet, and body are stained,
Water washes away the dirt.
When the clothes become polluted with urine,
They are washed clean with soap.
But when the intellect is stained by sin,
It is cleansed by the Dye of the Naam (Name of God).
One does not become virtuous or sinful just by speaking.
Actions performed are inscribed and taken along (after death).
As you sow, so shall you eat.
O Nanak, by His Command, you come and go (in reincarnation). ||20||
explanation: This pauri uses simple analogies to distinguish between physical and spiritual cleansing. It states that just as water cleanses physical dirt and soap cleanses dirty clothes, so too is the **intellect, when stained by sin, purified by the 'Dye of the Naam' (God's Name)**. It then moves to the crucial concept of **karma**, stating that one is not determined good or bad by mere words, but by their **actions ('karnaa')**, which are recorded and carried with the soul. The universal law of **'as you sow, so shall you reap'** is asserted. The pauri concludes by reaffirming that the cycle of birth and death is also subject to **God's Command ('Hukam')**, tying human actions and their consequences back to the Divine Will.

pauri_punjabi:
ਤੀਰਥੁ ਤਪੁ ਦਇਆ ਦਤੁ ਦਾਨੁ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਪਾਵੈ ਤਿਲ ਕਾ ਮਾਨੁ ॥
ਸੁਣਿਆ ਮੰਨਿਆ ਮਨਿ ਕੀਤਾ ਭਾਉ ॥
ਅੰਤਰਗਤਿ ਤੀਰਥਿ ਮਲੁ ਨਾਉ ॥
ਸਭਿ ਗੁਣ ਤੇਰੇ ਮੈ ਨਾਹੀ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਵਿਣੁ ਗੁਣ ਕੀਤੇ ਭਗਤਿ ਨ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਸੁਅਸਤਿ ਆਥਿ ਬਾਣੀ ਬਰਮਾਉ ॥
ਸਤਿ ਸੁਹਾਣੁ ਸਦਾ ਮਨਿ ਚਾਉ ॥
ਕਵਣੁ ਸੁ ਵੇਲਾ ਵਖਤੁ ਕਵਣੁ ਕਵਣ ਥਿਤਿ ਕਵਣੁ ਵਾਰੁ ॥
ਕਵਣਿ ਸਿ ਰੁਤੀ ਮਾਹੁ ਕਵਣੁ ਜਿਤੁ ਹੋਆ ਆਕਾਰੁ ॥
ਵੇਲ ਨ ਪਾਈਆ ਪੰਡਤੀ ਜਿ ਹੋਵੈ ਲੇਖੁ ਪੁਰਾਣੁ ॥
ਵਖਤੁ ਨ ਪਾਇਓ ਕਾਦੀਆ ਜਿ ਲਿਖਨਿ ਲੇਖੁ ਕੁਰਾਣੁ ॥
ਥਿਤਿ ਵਾਰੁ ਨ ਜੋਗੀ ਜਾਣੈ ਰੁਤਿ ਮਾਹੁ ਨ ਕੋਈ ॥
ਜਾ ਕਰਤਾ ਸਿਰਠੀ ਕਉ ਸਾਜੇ ਆਪੇ ਜਾਣੈ ਸੋਈ ॥
ਕਿਵ ਕਰਿ ਆਖਾ ਕਿਵ ਸਾਲਾਹੀ ਕਿਉ ਵਰਨਾ ਕਿਵ ਜਾਣਾ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਆਖਣਿ ਸਭੁ ਕੋ ਆਖੈ ਇਕ ਦੂ ਇਕੁ ਸਿਆਣਾ ॥
ਵਡਾ ਸਾਹਿਬੁ ਵਡੀ ਨਾਈ ਕੀਤਾ ਕਾ ਜਾ ਕਾ ਹੋਵੈ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਜੇ ਕੋ ਆਪੌ ਜਾਣੈ ਅਗੈ ਗਇਆ ਨ ਸੋਹੈ ॥੨੧॥
transliteration:
Teerath tap da-i-aa dat daan.
Je ko paavai til kaa maan.
Suni-aa manni-aa man keetaa bhaa-o.
Antargat teerath mal naa-o.
Sabh gun tere mai naahee ko-e.
Vin gun keete bhagat na ho-e.
Su-asath aath baanee barma-o.
Sat suhaN sadaa man chaa-o.
Kavan su velaa vakhat kavan kavan thit kavan vaar.
Kavan si rutee maahu kavan jit ho-aa aakaar.
Vel na paa-ee-aa pandtee je hovai lekh puraan.
Vakhat na paa-i-o kaadee-aa je likhan lekh kuraan.
Thit vaar na jogee jaanai rut maahu na ko-ee.
Jaa kartaa sirthee ka-o saaje aape jaanai so-ee.
Kiv kar aakhaa kiv saalaahee ki-o varna kiv jaanaa.
Naanak aakhan sabh ko aakhai ik doo ik si-aana.
Vadaa Saahib vadee naa-ee keetaa kaa jaa kaa hovai.
Naanak je ko aapau jaanai agai ga-i-aa na sohai. ||21||
translation:
Pilgrimage, austere discipline, compassion, and charity—
If anyone receives even a tiny bit of honor from these.
But by listening, believing, and cherishing love in the heart,
One bathes in the sacred shrine of the inner self and washes away filth.
All virtues are Yours, I have none.
Without virtues, devotional worship cannot be performed.
Hail to the Creator, whose Word is the Vedas.
Truth is beautiful, and my mind is forever joyous.
What was that time, what was that moment, what was that lunar day, what was that week day?
What was that season, what was that month, when the universe was created?
No Pundit (scholar) found that time, even if it were written in the Puranas.
No Qazi (Islamic judge/scholar) found that time, even if it were written in the Quran.
No Yogi knows the lunar day, the week day, the season, or the month.
Only the Creator, who fashioned the creation, knows that time Himself.
How can I speak of Him? How can I praise Him? How can I describe Him? How can I know Him?
O Nanak, everyone speaks, each one claiming to be wiser than the next.
Great is the Lord, and great is His Name; whatever He does, that comes to pass.
O Nanak, if anyone thinks they know Him by themselves, they will not be honored in the world hereafter. ||21||
explanation: This profound pauri explores the relative value of various spiritual practices. It states that while external practices like **pilgrimage, austerities, compassion, and charity** may grant some worldly recognition, true purification comes from **listening, believing, and cultivating love for God within the heart**, which is likened to bathing in the sacred shrine of the inner self. Guru Nanak expresses his humility, acknowledging that all virtues belong to God and without them, true devotion is impossible. He then praises the Creator whose **'Bani' (Word)** is the essence of all scriptures. A significant portion of this pauri then delves into the **unknowability of the time of creation**. Neither Hindu Pundits with their Puranas nor Muslim Qazis with their Quran, nor Yogis, can ascertain the exact moment of creation; **only the Creator Himself knows**. Guru Nanak then humbly questions his own capacity to describe or know God, observing that everyone claims wisdom. The pauri concludes by reiterating God's greatness and the certainty of His will. It cautions against **ego ('aapau jaanai')** and self-proclaimed knowledge, emphasizing that such arrogance will not be honored in the afterlife. This verse powerfully reinforces God's omnipotence and the futility of human attempts to fully grasp His mysteries through intellect alone.

pauri_punjabi:
ਪਾਤਾਲਾ ਪਾਤਾਲ ਲਖ ਆਗਾਸਾ ਆਗਾਸ ॥
ਓੜਕ ਓੜਕ ਭਾਲਿ ਥਕੇ ਵੇਦ ਕਹਨਿ ਇਕ ਵਾਤ ॥
ਸਹਸ ਅਠਾਰਹ ਕਹਨਿ ਕਤੇਬਾ ਅਸੁਲੂ ਇਕ ਧਾਤੁ ॥
ਲੇਖਾ ਹੋਇ ਤ ਲਿਖੀਐ ਲੇਖੈ ਹੋਇ ਵਿਣਾਸੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਵਡਾ ਆਖੀਐ ਆਪੇ ਜਾਣੈ ਆਪੁ ॥੨੨॥
transliteration:
Paataalaa paataal lakh aagaasaa aagaas.
Orhak orhak bhaali thake ved kahani ik vaat.
Sahas athaarh kahan katebaa asuloo ik dhaat.
Lekhaa ho-e ta likhee-ai lekhai ho-e vinaas.
Naanak vadaa aakhee-ai aape jaanai aap. ||22||
translation:
There are hundreds of thousands of nether worlds below, and skies above skies.
Explorers have searched to their limits and grown weary, while the Vedas speak of only one reality.
The Semitic scriptures speak of eighteen thousand worlds, but the ultimate reality is One Principle.
If there were a count, it could be written, but the count itself would be consumed.
O Nanak, call Him Great; He Himself knows Himself. ||22||
explanation: This pauri emphasizes the **immeasurable vastness of God's creation**. It speaks of countless lower and upper realms ('paataalaa paataal lakh aagaasaa aagaas'), highlighting that seekers and scriptures (Vedas and Semitic texts like the Quran and Bible) have tried to define the limits of creation, but even their descriptions are limited. The Vedas might speak of 'one reality', and other scriptures of 'eighteen thousand worlds', but the underlying principle is always the **One God**. The verse asserts that if creation could be counted, it would be written down, but its very vastness implies that any attempt at enumeration would be overwhelmed and consumed. The conclusion is that God is too great to be fully known by human intellect; **He alone knows Himself**. This underscores His transcendence and the futility of trying to limit Him through human categorization.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸਾਲਾਹੀ ਸਾਲਾਹਿ ਏਤੀ ਸੁਰਤਿ ਨ ਪਾਈਆ ॥
ਨਦੀਆ ਅਤੈ ਵਾਹ ਪਵਹਿ ਸਮੁੰਦਿ ਨ ਜਾਣੀਅਹਿ ॥
ਸਮੁੰਦ ਸਾਹ ਸੁਲਤਾਨ ਗਿਰਹਾ ਸੇਤੀ ਮਾਲੁ ਧਨੁ ॥
ਕੀੜੀ ਤੁਲਿ ਨ ਹੋਵਨੀ ਜੇ ਤਿਸੁ ਨਦਰਿ ਨ ਆਵਨੀ ॥੨੩॥
transliteration:
Saalaahee saalaahi etee surat na paa-ee-aa.
Nadee-aa atai vaah pavahi samund na jaanee-ah.
Samund Saah Sultan girhaa setee maal dhan.
Keerhee tul na hovnee je tis nadar na aavnee. ||23||
translation:
Even if we praise Him, praising Him, we cannot attain such understanding.
Rivers and streams flow into the ocean, but they do not know its expanse.
Even kings and emperors, with mountains of wealth and property,
Are not equal to an ant, if they do not receive His Glance of Grace. ||23||
explanation: This pauri reiterates the idea that **God's greatness is beyond full human comprehension**, even through constant praise. It uses the analogy of **rivers flowing into the ocean**; just as the rivers do not grasp the ocean's immensity, so too human praise cannot fully encompass God's vastness. The verse then employs a powerful comparison: even the mightiest **kings and emperors, with all their immense wealth**, are less than an **ant** if they do not receive **God's Gracious Glance ('Nadar')**. This highlights that all worldly power and riches are trivial without divine grace, emphasizing the supremacy of God's benevolent favor over all material possessions and human status.

pauri_punjabi:
ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਸਿਫਤੀ ਕਹਣਿ ਨ ਅੰਤੁ ॥
ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਕਰਣੈ ਦੇਣਿ ਨ ਅੰਤੁ ॥
ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਵੇਖਣਿ ਸੁਣਣਿ ਨ ਅੰਤੁ ॥
ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਜਾਪੈ ਕਿਆ ਮਨਿ ਮੰਤੁ ॥
ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਜਾਪੈ ਕੀਤਾ ਆਕਾਰੁ ॥
ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਜਾਪੈ ਪਾਰਾਵਾਰੁ ॥
ਅੰਤ ਕਾਰਣਿ ਕੇਤੇ ਬਿਲਲਾਹਿ ॥
ਤਾ ਕੇ ਅੰਤ ਨ ਪਾਏ ਜਾਹਿ ॥
ਏਹੁ ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਜਾਣੈ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਬਹੁਤਾ ਕਹੀਐ ਬਹੁਤਾ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਵਡਾ ਸਾਹਿਬੁ ਊਚਾ ਥਾਉ ॥
ਊਚੇ ਉਪਰਿ ਊਚਾ ਨਾਉ ॥
ਏਵਡੁ ਊਚਾ ਹੋਵੈ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਤਿਸੁ ਊਚੇ ਕਉ ਜਾਣੈ ਸੋਇ ॥
ਜੇਵਡੁ ਆਪਿ ਜਾਣੈ ਆਪਿ ਆਪਿ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਨਦਰੀ ਕਰਮੀ ਦਾਤਿ ॥੨੪॥
transliteration:
Ant na siftee kahan na ant.
Ant na karnai den na ant.
Ant na vekhan sunan na ant.
Ant na jaapai ki-aa man mant.
Ant na jaapai keetaa aakaar.
Ant na jaapai paaraavaar.
Ant kaaran kete billaahi.
Taa ke ant na paa-e jaahi.
Eh ant na jaanai ko-e.
Bahutaa kahee-ai bahutaa ho-e.
Vadaa Saahib oochaa thaa-o.
Ooche upar oochaa Naa-o.
Evad oochaa hovai ko-e.
Tisu ooche ka-o jaanai so-e.
Jevad Aap jaanai Aap Aap.
Naanak nadaree karmee daat. ||24||
translation:
There is no end to His praises, no end to speaking of Him.
There is no end to His doing, no end to His giving.
There is no end to His seeing, no end to His hearing.
His inner counsel and wisdom cannot be known.
There is no end to His created universe.
There is no end to His limits or boundaries.
Many cry out to know His limits,
But His limits cannot be found.
No one knows these limits.
The more you speak of them, the more there are.
Great is the Lord, and exalted is His dwelling place.
Sublimely exalted is His Name.
If someone were to be as great as He is,
Only then could they know that Exalted One.
As Great as He is, He Himself knows His own greatness.
O Nanak, by His Glance of Grace, one receives gifts. ||24||
explanation: This pauri strongly emphasizes the **infinite and boundless nature of God**. It uses the word **'Ant' (end/limit)** repeatedly to state that there is no end to His praises, actions, gifts, seeing, hearing, inner wisdom, created universe, or boundaries. Many try to find His limits, but they remain undiscovered. The more one attempts to describe Him, the more His vastness becomes apparent. God is depicted as the **Great Lord, with an exalted dwelling and an even more exalted Name**. The only one who can truly know God's greatness is someone as great as He is, which is impossible for humans. Therefore, **only God Himself truly knows His own vastness**. The pauri concludes by reiterating that all **spiritual gifts and blessings are received through God's Grace ('Nadar') and divine will ('Karmee')**, not through human effort to comprehend His infinitude.

pauri_punjabi:
ਬਹੁਤਾ ਕਰਮੁ ਲਿਖਿਆ ਨਾ ਜਾਇ ॥
ਵਡਾ ਦਾਤਾ ਤਿਲੁ ਨ ਤਮਾਇ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਮੰਗਹਿ ਜੋਧ ਅਪਾਰ ॥
ਕੇਤਿਆ ਗਣਤ ਨਹੀ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਖਪਿ ਤੁਟਹਿ ਵੇਕਾਰ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਲੈ ਲੈ ਮੁਕਰੁ ਪਾਹਿ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਮੂਰਖ ਖਾਹੀ ਖਾਹਿ ॥
ਕੇਤਿਆ ਦੂਖ ਭੂਖ ਸਦ ਮਾਰ ॥
ਏਹਿ ਭਿ ਦਾਤਿ ਤੇਰੀ ਦਾਤਾਰ ॥
ਬੰਦਿ ਖਲਾਸੀ ਭਾਣੈ ਹੋਇ ॥
ਹੋਰੁ ਆਖਿ ਨ ਸਕੈ ਕੋਇ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਖਾਇਕੁ ਆਖਣਿ ਪਾਇ ॥
ਓਹੁ ਜਾਣੈ ਜੇਤੀਆ ਮੁਹਿ ਖਾਇ ॥
ਆਪੇ ਜਾਣੈ ਆਪੇ ਦੇਇ ॥
ਆਖਹਿ ਸਿ ਭਿ ਕੇਈ ਕੇਇ ॥
ਜਿਸ ਨੋ ਬਖਸੇ ਸਿਫਤਿ ਸਾਲਾਹ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਪਾਤਿਸਾਹੀ ਪਾਤਿਸਾਹੁ ॥੨੫॥
transliteration:
Bahutaa karam likhi-aa na jaae.
Vadaa Daataa til na tamaa-e.
Kete mangahi jodh apaar.
Keti-aa ganat nahee veechaar.
Kete khap tutahi vekaar.
Kete lai lai mukar paahi.
Kete moorakh khaahee khaahi.
Keti-aa dookh bhookh sad maar.
Eh bhi daat teree Daataar.
Band khalaasee bhaNai ho-e.
Hor aakh na sakai ko-e.
Je ko khaa-ik aakhan paae.
Oh jaanai jetee-aa muh khaae.
Aape jaanai aape de-e.
Aakhahi si bhi ke-ee ke-e.
Jis no bakhse sifat saalaah.
Naanak Paatisaahee Paatisaah. ||25||
translation:
His great blessings cannot be written.
He is the Great Giver, not even a tiny bit greedy.
So many mighty warriors beg from Him.
So many whose number and thoughts cannot be counted.
So many waste away, consumed by their vices.
So many receive, and then deny receiving.
So many fools simply eat and eat.
So many suffer pain, hunger, and constant torment.
O Giver, even these are Your gifts (due to His Hukam).
Freedom from bondage comes by His Will.
No one else can utter it.
If a fool tries to speak (of His gifts as if they were his own),
He knows how many blows he will receive in his mouth.
He Himself knows, He Himself gives.
Very few speak of this.
Upon whom He bestows the gift of His praise and glory,
O Nanak, He is the King of kings. ||25||
explanation: This pauri emphasizes the **boundless generosity of God ('Vadaa Daataa')** and His lack of any desire or greed. It speaks of countless beings who beg from Him, both the powerful and the innumerable. It also highlights the diverse states of humanity: those consumed by vice, those who deny receiving His gifts, those who indulge excessively, and those who suffer constant pain and hunger. Remarkably, Guru Nanak states that **even these diverse conditions (including suffering) are also His gifts**, implying they are part of His divine plan or 'Hukam'. The pauri reiterates that **liberation from bondage comes only by God's Will ('BhaNai')**. It cautions against anyone claiming to understand or speak for God's giving, implying such arrogance would lead to rebuke. Ultimately, **God Himself knows and gives**, and only those **blessed by Him with the gift of praise** truly understand His nature. The pauri concludes by calling God the **'King of kings' (Paatisaahee Paatisaah)**, affirming His supreme sovereignty and generosity.

pauri_punjabi:
ਅਮੁਲ ਗੁਣ ਅਮੁਲ ਵਾਪਾਰ ॥
ਅਮੁਲ ਵਾਪਾਰੀਏ ਅਮੁਲ ਭੰਡਾਰ ॥
ਅਮੁਲ ਆਵਹਿ ਅਮੁਲ ਲੈ ਜਾਹਿ ॥
ਅਮੁਲ ਭਾਇ ਅਮੁਲਾ ਸਮਾਹਿ ॥
ਅਮੁਲੁ ਧਰਮੁ ਅਮੁਲੁ ਦੀਬਾਣੁ ॥
ਅਮੁਲੁ ਤੁਲੁ ਅਮੁਲੁ ਪਰਵਾਣੁ ॥
ਅਮੁਲੁ ਕਰਮੁ ਅਮੁਲੁ ਫੁਰਮਾਣੁ ॥
ਅਮੁਲੋ ਅਮੁਲੁ ਆਖਿਆ ਨ ਜਾਇ ॥
ਆਖਿ ਆਖਿ ਰਹੇ ਲਿਵ ਲਾਇ ॥
ਤੋਲਿ ਤੋਲਿ ਨਾ ਤੋਲਿਆ ਜਾਇ ॥
ਵਖਰ ਏਵਡੁ ਰਹੇ ਸਮਾਇ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਜਿਨ ਕੈ ਭਾਗਿ ਨਾਮੁ ॥
ਅਨਦਿਨੁ ਨਾਮੁ ਸਚਾ ਪਤਿ ਸਾਚਾ ॥੨੬॥
transliteration:
Amul gun amul vaapaar.
Amul vaapaaree-e amul bhandaar.
Amul aavahi amul lai jaahi.
Amul bhaa-e amulaa samaahi.
Amul Dharam amul deebaan.
Amul tul amul parvaan.
Amul karam amul furmaan.
Amulo amul aakhi-aa na jaae.
Aakh aakh rahe liv laae.
Toli toli naa toli-aa jaae.
Vakhar evad rahe samaa-e.
Naanak jin kai bhaag Naam.
An-din Naam Sachaa Pat Saachaa. ||26||
translation:
Priceless are His virtues, priceless His commerce.
Priceless are the merchants, priceless His stores.
Priceless are those who come, priceless those who go.
Priceless is His love, priceless those who merge in Him.
Priceless is His Righteousness, priceless His Court.
Priceless is His balance, priceless His measure.
Priceless is His Grace, priceless His Command.
Priceless, priceless, beyond all description.
Speakers speak, absorbed in meditation, but cannot describe Him.
Weighers weigh, but cannot weigh Him.
Such is the vastness of this merchandise (of the Name) that it fills everything.
O Nanak, those who are blessed with the Name in their destiny,
Meditate on the Name, the True Name, the True Master, day and night. ||26||
explanation: This pauri extensively uses the word **'Amul' (priceless, invaluable, beyond measure)** to describe various aspects of God and His creation. It highlights the pricelessness of His **virtues, the spiritual 'commerce' of divine love, the devotees who engage in it, and His boundless stores of grace**. It extends to His **righteousness, divine court, justice (balance and measure), grace, and command**. The central message is that God is **'Amulo Amul' – utterly priceless and beyond all description and measurement**. Despite endless attempts by seekers to describe Him, He remains incomprehensible in His totality. The verse concludes by stating that those **destined by grace to receive the Naam (Name of God)** find true fulfillment by meditating on it day and night, affirming the **True Name and the True Master** as the ultimate reality.

pauri_punjabi:
ਸੋ ਦਰੁ ਕੇਹਾ ਸੋ ਘਰੁ ਕੇਹਾ ਜਿਤੁ ਬਹਿ ਸਰਬ ਸਮਾਲੇ ॥
ਵਾਜੇ ਨਾਦ ਅਨੇਕ ਅਸੰਖਾ ਕੇਤੇ ਵਾਵਣਹਾਰੇ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਰਾਗ ਪਰੀ ਸਿਉ ਕਹੀਅਨਿ ਕੇਤੇ ਗਾਵਣਹਾਰੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਤੁਹਨੋ ਪਉਣੁ ਪਾਣੀ ਬੈਸੰਤਰੁ ਗਾਵੈ ਰਾਜਾ ਧਰਮੁ ਦੁਆਰੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਚਿਤੁ ਗੁਪਤੁ ਲਿਖਿ ਜਾਣਹਿ ਲਿਖਿ ਲਿਖਿ ਧਰਮੁ ਵੀਚਾਰੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਈਸਰੁ ਬਰਮਾ ਦੇਵੀ ਸੋਹਨਿ ਤੇਰੇ ਸਦਾ ਸਵਾਰੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਇੰਦ ਇੰਦਾਸਣਿ ਬੈਠੇ ਦੇਵਤਿਆ ਦਰਿ ਨਾਲੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਸਿਧ ਸਮਾਧੀ ਅੰਦਰਿ ਗਾਵਨਿ ਸਾਧ ਵਿਚਾਰੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਨਿ ਜਤੀ ਸਤੀ ਸੰਤੋਖੀ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਵੀਰ ਕਰਾਰੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਨਿ ਪੰਡਿਤ ਪੜਨਿ ਰਖੀਸਰ ਜੁਗੁ ਜੁਗੁ ਵੇਦਾ ਨਾਲੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਮੋਹਣੀਆ ਮਨੁ ਮੋਹਨਿ ਸੁਰਗੁ ਮਛੁ ਪਇਆਲੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਨਿ ਰਤਨ ਉਪਾਏ ਤੇਰੇ ਅਠਸਠਿ ਤੀਰਥ ਨਾਲੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਜੋਧ ਮਹਾਬਲ ਸੂਰਾ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਖਾਣੀ ਚਾਰੇ ॥
ਗਾਵਹਿ ਖੰਡ ਮੰਡਲ ਵਰਭੰਡਾ ਕਰਿ ਕਰਿ ਰਖੇ ਧਾਰੇ ॥
ਸੇਈ ਤੁਧੁਨੋ ਗਾਵਹਿ ਜੋ ਤੁਧੁ ਭਾਵਨਿ ਰਤੇ ਤੇਰੇ ਭਗਤ ਰਸਾਲੇ ॥
ਹੋਰਿ ਕੇਤੇ ਗਾਵਨਿ ਸੇ ਮੈ ਚਿਤਿ ਨ ਆਵਨਿ ਨਾਨਕੁ ਕਹੈ ਵੀਚਾਰੇ ॥
ਜੋ ਤਿਸੁ ਭਾਵੈ ਸੋਈ ਕਰਸੀ ਹੁਕਮੁ ਨ ਕਰਣਾ ਜਾਈ ॥
ਸੋ ਪਾਤਿਸਾਹੁ ਸਾਹਾ ਪਾਤਿਸਾਹਿਬੁ ਨਾਨਕ ਰਹਣੁ ਰਜਾਈ ॥੨੭॥
transliteration:
So Dar kehaa so Ghar kehaa jit bah sarab samaale.
Vaaje Naad anek asankhaa kete vaavanhaare.
Kete Raag paree si-o kahee-an kete gaavanhaare.
Gaavahi tuhno pa-un paanee baisantar gaavai Raajaa Dharam duaare.
Gaavahi Chit Gupt likh jaanahi likh likh Dharam veechaare.
Gaavahi Eesar Barmaa Devee sohni tere sadaa savaare.
Gaavahi Ind Indaasan baithhe devti-aa dar naale.
Gaavahi Sidh samaadhee andar gaavan saadh veechaare.
Gaavan jatee satee santokhee gaavahi veer karaare.
Gaavan pandit paran rakheesar jug jug vedaa naale.
Gaavahi mohanee-aa man mohan surag machh pa-i-aale.
Gaavan ratan upaa-e tere athsath teerath naale.
Gaavahi jodh mahaabal sooraa gaavahi khaanee chaare.
Gaavahi khand mandal varbhandaa kar kar rakhe dhaare.
Se-ee tudhuno gaavahi jo tudh bhaavan rate tere bhagat rasaale.
Hore kete gaavan se mai chit na aavan Naanak kahai veechaare.
Jo tis bhaavai so-ee karsee hukam na karnaa jaa-ee.
So Paatisaahu saahaa paatisaahib Naanak rahan rajaa-ee. ||27||
translation:
How great is that Door, and how great is that House, where You sit and take care of all!
Innumerable are the musical instruments and melodies played there, and countless are the players.
Innumerable are the ragas (melodies) with their consorts, and countless are the singers.
The air, water, and fire sing of You; the Righteous Judge, Dharmaraj, sings at Your Door.
Chitra and Gupt (scribes of deeds) sing of You, who know how to record and judge righteousness.
Shiva, Brahma, and the Goddesses sing of You, forever beautiful in Your creations.
Indra, seated on his throne, sings of You, along with the demi-gods at Your Door.
The Siddhas (perfected ones) sing of You in their meditative trance; the humble sages sing of You.
The celibates, the chaste, the content, and the mighty warriors sing of You.
The Pandits (scholars) who read and the great Rishis (sages) of the ages, along with the Vedas, sing of You.
The enchanting beauties who enthrall the mind, in heaven, on earth, and in the nether regions, sing of You.
The jewels created by You, along with the sixty-eight sacred shrines, sing of You.
The mighty warriors and powerful heroes sing of You; the four sources of creation sing of You.
The continents, solar systems, and universes, created and established by You, sing of You.
Only those sing of You who are pleasing to You, immersed in Your sweet devotion, Your loving devotees.
Many others sing, but they do not come to my mind; Nanak speaks this reflection.
Whatever pleases Him, that alone He does; His Command cannot be overruled.
He is the King of kings, the Supreme Sovereign; O Nanak, live according to His Will. ||27||
explanation: This lengthy and majestic pauri is a grand hymn of praise, describing the **countless forms of creation that sing praises to God**. It begins by asking about the nature of God's 'Door' and 'House' from where He sustains all. It then enumerates various aspects of existence that sing of Him: musical instruments and melodies, the fundamental elements (air, water, fire), the **Lord of Righteousness (Dharamraj)**, the celestial scribes (Chitra and Gupt), various deities (Shiva, Brahma, Goddesses, Indra), spiritual practitioners (Siddhas, sages, celibates, chaste, content, warriors), scholars (Pandits, Rishis, Vedas), celestial beauties, the earth's jewels, pilgrimage sites, heroic figures, the **four sources of creation (from egg, womb, sweat, earth)**, and all the cosmic realms (continents, planets, universes). The pauri emphasizes that **only those who are pleasing to God, His loving devotees, truly sing His praises**. It ends by stating that many others sing, but they are beyond Guru Nanak's count. The powerful conclusion reiterates that **God's will is supreme and cannot be overruled**, and that He is the **King of kings**. The ultimate message is to **live in accordance with His divine will ('Rahan Raja-ee')**.

pauri_punjabi:
ਮੁੰਦਾ ਸੰਤੋਖੁ ਸਰਮੁ ਪਤੁ ਝੋਲੀ ਧਿਆਨ ਕੀ ਕਰਹਿ ਬਿਭੂਤਿ ॥
ਖਿੰਥਾ ਕਾਲ ਕੁਆਰੀ ਕਾਇਆ ਜੁਗਤਿ ਡੰਡਾ ਪਰਤੀਤਿ ॥
ਆਈ ਪੰਥੀ ਸਗਲ ਜਮਾਤੀ ਮਨਿ ਜੀਤੈ ਜਗੁ ਜੀਤੁ ॥
ਆਦੇਸੁ ਤਿਸੈ ਆਦੇਸੁ ॥
ਆਦਿ ਅਨੀਲੁ ਅਨਾਦਿ ਅਨਾਹਤਿ ਜੁਗੁ ਜੁਗੁ ਏਕੋ ਵੇਸੁ ॥੨੮॥
transliteration:
Munda santokh saram pat jholee dhi-aan kee karahi bibhoot.
Khinthhaa kaal kuaaree kaa-i-aa jugat dandaa parteet.
A-ee panthee sagal jamaatee man jeetai jag jeet.
Aades tisai aades.
Aad aneel anaad anaahat jug jug eko ves. ||28||
translation:
Let contentment be your ear-rings, modesty your begging bowl and pouch, and meditation the ashes you apply.
Let the thought of death be your patched coat, the chastity of your body your way, and faith your staff.
Let the A-i Panth (the highest Yogi sect) be all humankind, and conquering your mind be the conquest of the world.
I bow to Him, I humbly bow.
The Primal One, the Pure One, without beginning, without end, remaining the same through all ages. ||28||
explanation: This pauri adopts the terminology of **Yoga and asceticism** but redefines them spiritually. Guru Nanak transforms the external symbols of a Yogi into internal virtues: **contentment** becomes the ear-rings, **modesty** the begging bowl, and **meditation** the ashes smeared on the body. The awareness of **death (mortality)** becomes the patched cloak, **chastity** the true yogic discipline, and **faith** the staff. The highest 'Panth' (sect) is then declared to be **all humanity**, and the ultimate victory is not over the world but over one's own **mind ('man jeetai jag jeet')**. The pauri concludes with a profound salutation: **'Aades' (I bow)** to the Primal, Pure, Beginningless, and Indestructible Lord who remains eternally the same. This verse emphasizes inner transformation and universal brotherhood over outward ritualism and sectarianism.

pauri_punjabi:
ਭੁਗਤਿ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਦਇਆ ਭੰਡਾਰਣਿ ਘਟਿ ਘਟਿ ਵਾਜਹਿ ਨਾਦ ॥
ਆਪਿ ਨਾਥੁ ਨਾਥੀ ਸਭ ਜਾ ਕੀ ਰਿਧਿ ਸਿਧਿ ਅਵਰਾ ਸਾਦ ॥
ਸੰਜੋਗੁ ਵਿਜੋਗੁ ਦੁਇ ਕਾਰ ਚਲਾਵਹਿ ਲੇਖੇ ਆਵਹਿ ਭਾਗ ॥
ਆਦੇਸੁ ਤਿਸੈ ਆਦੇਸੁ ॥
ਆਦਿ ਅਨੀਲੁ ਅਨਾਦਿ ਅਨਾਹਤਿ ਜੁਗੁ ਜੁਗੁ ਏਕੋ ਵੇਸੁ ॥੨੯॥
transliteration:
Bhugat gi-aan da-i-aa bhandaaran ghat ghat vaajahi Naad.
Aap naath naathee sabh jaa kee ridh sidh avraa saad.
Sanjog vijog du-e kaar chalaavahi lekhe aavahi bhaag.
Aades tisai aades.
Aad aneel anaad anaahat jug jug eko ves. ||29||
translation:
Let spiritual knowledge be your food, and compassion your dispenser; in every heart, the Divine Melody resounds.
He Himself is the Master, over all He casts His power; spiritual powers and miraculous attainments are just other tastes.
Union and separation are the two ways by which He runs the world; by destiny, destinies are received.
I bow to Him, I humbly bow.
The Primal One, the Pure One, without beginning, without end, remaining the same through all ages. ||29||
explanation: This pauri continues the spiritual reinterpretation of yogic concepts. **Spiritual knowledge ('giaan')** is the true sustenance, and **compassion ('da-i-aa')** is the dispenser of this food. The **Divine Melody ('Naad')** is not just heard externally but resonates within every heart. God is the ultimate **Master ('Naath')** who controls everything; all miraculous powers ('ridh sidh') are secondary and merely distractions. The universe operates on the principle of **'Sanjog' (union)** and **'Vijog' (separation)**, and individuals receive their destinies according to their karma. The pauri concludes with the same reverential salutation to the **eternal, unchanging, Primal Lord**, reinforcing His supreme control over creation and destiny, and highlighting the spiritual over the miraculous.

pauri_punjabi:
ਏਕਾ ਮਾਈ ਜੁਗਤਿ ਵਿਆਈ ਤਿਨਿ ਚੇਲੇ ਪਰਵਾਣੁ ॥
ਇਕੁ ਸੰਸਾਰੀ ਇਕੁ ਭੰਡਾਰੀ ਇਕੁ ਲਾਏ ਦੀਬਾਣੁ ॥
ਜਿਵ ਤਿਸੁ ਭਾਵੈ ਤਿਵੈ ਚਲਾਵੈ ਜਿਵ ਹੋਵੈ ਫੁਰਮਾਣੁ ॥
ਓਹੁ ਵੇਖੈ ਓਨਾ ਨਦਰਿ ਨ ਆਵੈ ਬਹੁਤਾ ਏਹੁ ਵਿਡਾਣੁ ॥
ਆਦੇਸੁ ਤਿਸੈ ਆਦੇਸੁ ॥
ਆਦਿ ਅਨੀਲੁ ਅਨਾਦਿ ਅਨਾਹਤਿ ਜੁਗੁ ਜੁਗੁ ਏਕੋ ਵੇਸੁ ॥੩੦॥
transliteration:
Ekaa Maa-ee jugat vi-aa-ee tin chele parvaan.
Ik sansaaree ik bhandaaree ik laae deebaan.
Jiv tis bhaavai tivai chalaavai jiv hovai furmaan.
Oh vekhai onaa nadar na aavai bahutaa eh vidaan.
Aades tisai aades.
Aad aneel anaad anaahat jug jug eko ves. ||30||
translation:
The One Divine Mother conceived and gave birth to the three accepted disciples.
One is the creator of the world, one is the sustainer, and one presides over justice.
As it pleases Him, so He directs them; as is His Command.
He watches over them, but they cannot see Him; how wonderful this is!
I bow to Him, I humbly bow.
The Primal One, the Pure One, without beginning, without end, remaining the same through all ages. ||30||
explanation: This pauri addresses the concept of the **Hindu Trinity (Brahma, Vishnu, Shiva)**, not as independent deities but as manifestations of the **One Divine Mother (Maya/Divine Power)**, who herself is a product of the One God. It describes them as accepted 'chele' (disciples) performing their cosmic functions: one as the **creator ('sansaaree')**, one as the **sustainer ('bhandaaree')**, and one as the **judge/destroyer ('laae deebaan')**. The crucial point is that they operate entirely according to **God's pleasure and Command ('furmaan')**. The supreme wonder is that **God oversees them, but they cannot perceive Him**. The repeated salutation to the **Primal, Formless, and unchanging Lord** reinforces His ultimate transcendence and sovereignty over all perceived divine roles and cosmic functions.

pauri_punjabi:
ਆਸਣੁ ਲੋਇ ਲੋਇ ਭੰਡਾਰ ॥
ਜੋ ਕਿਛੁ ਪਾਇਆ ਸੁ ਏਕਾ ਵਾਰ ॥
ਕਰਿ ਕਰਿ ਵੇਖੈ ਸਿਰਜਣਹਾਰੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਸਚੇ ਕੀ ਸਾਚੀ ਕਾਰ ॥
ਆਦੇਸੁ ਤਿਸੈ ਆਦੇਸੁ ॥
ਆਦਿ ਅਨੀਲੁ ਅਨਾਦਿ ਅਨਾਹਤਿ ਜੁਗੁ ਜੁਗੁ ਏਕੋ ਵੇਸੁ ॥੩੧॥
transliteration:
Aasan lo-e lo-e bhandaar.
Jo kichh paa-i-aa so ekaa vaar.
Kar kar vekhai Sirjanhaar.
Naanak Sache kee Saachee Kaar.
Aades tisai aades.
Aad aneel anaad anaahat jug jug eko ves. ||31||
translation:
His seat is in every world, and His storehouses are in every world.
Whatever He placed (created) was all at once.
The Creator creates, and watches over His creation.
O Nanak, true is the work of the True One.
I bow to Him, I humbly bow.
The Primal One, the Pure One, without beginning, without end, remaining the same through all ages. ||31||
explanation: This pauri speaks to God's **omnipresence and omnipotence**. It states that God's **'Aasan' (seat/presence)** is in every world, and His **'Bhandaar' (storehouses of creation and sustenance)** are likewise pervasive. The creation was not a gradual process but a single, instantaneous act: **'Jo kichh paa-i-aa so ekaa vaar'**. The **Creator ('Sirjanhaar')** continuously creates and watches over His creation. Guru Nanak affirms that the **'kaar' (work or action) of the True One is always true and perfect**. The pauri concludes with the customary salutation to the **eternal, unchanging, Primal Lord**, emphasizing His simultaneous immanence (present everywhere) and transcendence (beyond all limits).

pauri_punjabi:
ਇਕ ਦੂ ਜੀਭੌ ਲਖ ਹੋਹਿ ਲਖ ਹੋਵਹਿ ਲਖ ਵੀਸ ॥
ਲਖੁ ਲਖੁ ਗੇੜਾ ਆਖੀਅਹਿ ਏਕੁ ਨਾਮੁ ਜਗਦੀਸ ॥
ਏਤੁ ਰਾਹਿ ਪਤਿ ਪਵੜੀਆ ਚੜੀਐ ਹੋਇ ਇਕੀਸ ॥
ਸੁਣਿ ਗਲਾ ਆਕਾਸ ਕੀ ਕੀਟਾ ਆਈ ਰੀਸ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਨਦਰੀ ਪਾਈਐ ਕੂੜੀ ਕੂੜੈ ਠੀਸ ॥੩੨॥
transliteration:
Ik doo jeebhau lakh hohi lakh hovahi lakh vees.
Lakhu lakhu geraa aakhee-ah ek Naam Jagdees.
Et raahi pat pavarhee-aa charhee-ai ho-e ikees.
Sun galaa aakaas kee keetaa aa-ee rees.
Naanak nadaree paa-ee-ai koorhee koorhai thhees. ||32||
translation:
If I had a hundred thousand tongues, and then twenty times a hundred thousand more,
I would chant the Name of the Lord of the Universe hundreds of thousands of times.
By this path, by these steps, one ascends and becomes one with Him.
Upon hearing of the heavens, even worms desire to emulate them.
O Nanak, by His Glance of Grace, He is obtained; all false pride is useless. ||32||
explanation: This pauri expresses the **intense desire to chant the Divine Name**. Guru Nanak states that even if he possessed countless tongues, he would chant the **Name of God ('Ek Naam Jagdees') hundreds of thousands of times**. This chanting is presented as the **path and ladder ('pavarhee-aa') to ascend and become one with the Divine ('ho-e ikees')**. It implies that the aspiration to reach high spiritual states is natural, even for the humblest (like a worm wanting to emulate the heavens). However, the ultimate message is that **God is attained only through His Grace ('Nadar')**, not through human effort or pride. All false pride and empty boasts are futile in this spiritual pursuit.

pauri_punjabi:
ਆਖਣਿ ਜੋਰੁ ਚੁਪੈ ਨਹ ਜੋਰੁ ॥
ਜੋਰੁ ਨ ਮੰਗਣਿ ਦੇਣਿ ਨ ਜੋਰੁ ॥
ਜੋਰੁ ਨ ਜੀਵਣਿ ਮਰਣਿ ਨਹ ਜੋਰੁ ॥
ਜੋਰੁ ਨ ਰਾਜਿ ਮਾਲਿ ਮਨਿ ਸੋਰੁ ॥
ਜੋਰੁ ਨ ਸੁਰਤੀ ਗਿਆਨਿ ਵੀਚਾਰਿ ॥
ਜੋਰੁ ਨ ਜੁਗਤੀ ਛੁਟੈ ਸੰਸਾਰੁ ॥
ਜਿਸੁ ਹਥਿ ਜੋਰੁ ਕਰਿ ਵੇਖੈ ਸੋਇ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਉਤਮੁ ਨੀਚੁ ਨ ਕੋਇ ॥੩੩॥
transliteration:
Aakhan jor chupai nah jor.
Jor na mangan den na jor.
Jor na jeevan maran nah jor.
Jor na raaj maal man sor.
Jor na surtee gi-aan veechaar.
Jor na jugtee chhuttai sansaar.
Jis hath jor kar vekhai so-e.
Naanak utam neech na ko-e. ||33||
translation:
There is no power in speaking, no power in silence.
No power to beg, no power to give.
No power to live, no power to die.
No power in kingship, wealth, or mental clamor.
No power in spiritual understanding, wisdom, or meditation.
No power in finding the way to escape the world.
He alone has the power, in His hands, and He watches over all He has made.
O Nanak, no one is high or low. ||33||
explanation: This pauri profoundly underscores the **lack of true power in human hands**, asserting that all real power resides with God. It states that humans have no power in speaking or remaining silent, in giving or receiving, in living or dying. Worldly power, wealth, and mental intellectual pursuits also lack true 'jor' (power). Even spiritual understanding, wisdom, meditation, or finding methods to escape the cycle of reincarnation are not within human control. The core message is that **only God possesses true power**, and He orchestrates everything. The concluding line, **'Nanak utam neech na ko-e' (no one is high or low)**, signifies that in the eyes of the all-powerful God, human distinctions of status are meaningless, emphasizing equality and humility before the Divine.

pauri_punjabi:
ਰਾਤੀ ਰੁਤੀ ਥਿਤੀ ਵਾਰ ॥
ਪਵਣ ਪਾਣੀ ਅਗਨੀ ਪਾਤਾਲ ॥
ਤਿਸੁ ਵਿਚਿ ਧਰਤੀ ਥਾਪਿ ਰਖੀ ਧਰਮ ਸਾਲ ॥
ਤਿਸੁ ਵਿਚਿ ਜੀਅ ਜੁਗਤਿ ਕੇ ਰੰਗ ॥
ਤਿਨ ਕੇ ਨਾਮ ਅਨੇਕ ਅਨੰਤ ॥
ਕਰਮੀ ਕਰਮੀ ਹੋਇ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਸਚਾ ਆਪਿ ਸਚਾ ਦਰਬਾਰੁ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਸੋਹਨਿ ਪੰਚ ਪਰਵਾਣੁ ॥
ਨਦਰੀ ਕਰਮਿ ਪਵੈ ਨੀਸਾਣੁ ॥
ਕਚ ਪਕਾਈ ਓਥੈ ਪਾਇ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਗਇਆ ਜਾਪੈ ਜਾਇ ॥੩੪॥
transliteration:
Raatee rutee thitee vaar.
Pavan paanee agnee paataal.
Tisu vich dhartee thaap rakhee Dharam Saal.
Tisu vich jee-a jugat ke rang.
Tin ke Naam anek anant.
Karmee karmee ho-e veechaar.
Sachaa Aap Sachaa Darbaar.
Tithai sohni panch parvaan.
Nadree karam pavai neesaan.
Kach pakaa-ee othhai paae.
Naanak ga-i-aa jaapai jaae. ||34||
translation:
Nights, seasons, lunar days, and weekdays;
Air, water, fire, and the nether regions.
Amidst these, He established the Earth as the House of Dharma (righteousness).
Within it are beings of various kinds and colors (ways of life).
Their Names are countless and endless.
According to their actions, they are judged.
The Lord Himself is True, and True is His Court.
There, the five accepted ones (the spiritually evolved) look beautiful.
By His Glance of Grace, and by His actions, they receive the mark of approval.
There, the raw (unripe) and the ripe (spiritually mature) are distinguished.
O Nanak, when one goes there, this is truly known. ||34||
explanation: This pauri describes the **Earth as a 'Dharam Saal' (House of Righteousness or moral action)**, established by God amidst the cosmos, complete with nights, seasons, elements (air, water, fire), and various realms. It emphasizes the diversity of life on Earth, with countless beings and names. The core message is that **judgment ('veechaar') occurs based on one's 'karam' (actions)**. God Himself is Truth, and His **Divine Court ('Darbaar') is also true and just**. It is in this Court that the **'Panch' (spiritually accepted ones)** are honored. Their acceptance is not based on mere actions but primarily on **God's Grace ('Nadar') and His divine will ('karam')**, which marks them as approved. The pauri concludes that the distinction between the spiritually 'raw' (immature) and 'ripe' (mature) is made there, a truth that becomes evident upon reaching that Divine Court. This highlights the importance of righteous living and the ultimate role of divine grace in salvation.

pauri_punjabi:
ਧਰਮ ਖੰਡ ਕਾ ਏਹੋ ਧਰਮੁ ॥
ਗਿਆਨ ਖੰਡ ਕਾ ਆਖਹੁ ਕਰਮੁ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਪਵਣ ਪਾਣੀ ਵੈਸੰਤਰ ਕੇਤੇ ਕਾਨ ਮਹੇਸ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਬਰਮੇ ਘਾੜਤਿ ਘੜੀਅਹਿ ਰੂਪ ਰੰਗ ਕੇ ਵੇਸ ॥
ਕੇਤੀਆ ਕਰਮ ਭੂਮੀ ਮੇਰ ਕੇਤੇ ਕੇਤੇ ਧੂ ਉਪਦੇਸ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਇੰਦ ਚੰਦ ਸੂਰ ਕੇਤੇ ਕੇਤੇ ਮੰਡਲ ਦੇਸ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਸਿਧ ਬੁਧ ਨਾਥ ਕੇਤੇ ਕੇਤੇ ਦੇਵੀ ਵੇਸ ॥
ਕੇਤੇ ਦੇਵ ਦਾਨਵ ਮੁਨਿ ਕੇਤੇ ਕੇਤੇ ਰਤਨ ਸਮੁੰਦ ॥
ਕੇਤੀਆ ਖਾਣੀ ਕੇਤੀਆ ਬਾਣੀ ਕੇਤੇ ਪਾਤ ਨਰਿੰਦ ॥
ਕੇਤੀਆ ਸੁਰਤੀ ਸੇਵਕ ਕੇਤੇ ਨਾਨਕ ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਅੰਤੁ ॥੩੫॥
transliteration:
Dharam Khand kaa eho Dharam.
Gi-aan Khand kaa aakhahu karam.
Kete pavan paanee vaisantar kete kaan mahes.
Kete barme ghaarhat gharhee-ah roop rang ke ves.
Ketee-aa karam bhoomee mer kete kete Dhoo updes.
Kete Ind Chand Soor kete kete mandal des.
Kete Sidh Budh Naath kete kete Devee ves.
Kete dev daanav mun kete kete ratan samund.
Ketee-aa khaanee ketee-aa baanee kete paat narind.
Ketee-aa surtee sevak kete Naanak ant na ant. ||35||
translation:
This is the essence of the Realm of Righteousness.
Now, I shall describe the actions of the Realm of Knowledge:
So many airs, waters, and fires; so many Krishnas and Shivas.
So many Brahmas fashioned, creating forms, colors, and garbs.
So many lands of action (karma bhoomi), so many mountains, so many Dhruvs giving instruction.
So many Indras, so many moons and suns; so many worlds and lands.
So many Siddhas, Buddhas, and Naths; so many Goddesses.
So many gods, demons, and silent sages; so many jewels in the oceans.
So many sources of creation (from egg, womb, sweat, earth); so many languages; so many lines of kings.
So many enlightened ones, so many servants; O Nanak, there is no end to their ends. ||35||
explanation: This pauri is the first of five (35-38) describing the **'Panch Khand' or Five Realms/Stages of Spiritual Journey**. This pauri specifically discusses the **'Dharam Khand' (Realm of Righteousness)** and begins the description of **'Giaan Khand' (Realm of Knowledge)**. It uses **'Kete' (so many, countless)** to emphasize the incredible diversity and vastness of creation within the Realm of Knowledge. It enumerates countless elements (air, water, fire), Hindu deities (Krishna, Shiva, Brahma), forms, colors, lands of action, mountains, sages (like Dhruv), celestial bodies (Indras, moons, suns), worlds, spiritual masters (Siddhas, Buddhas, Naths), goddesses, gods, demons, munis, oceanic jewels, sources of creation, languages, and rulers. The repeated phrase **'ant na ant' (no end to their ends)** powerfully conveys the **limitless nature of God's creation within the Realm of Knowledge**, which is characterized by the vastness of diversity and forms. It suggests that in this realm, the seeker begins to grasp the sheer immensity and diversity of God's handiwork.

pauri_punjabi:
ਗਿਆਨ ਖੰਡ ਮਹਿ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਪਰਚੰਡੁ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਨਾਦ ਬਿਨੋਦ ਕੋਡ ਅਨੰਦੁ ॥
ਸਰਮ ਖੰਡ ਕੀ ਬਾਣੀ ਰੂਪੁ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਘਾੜਤਿ ਘੜੀਐ ਬਹੁਤੁ ਅਨੂਪੁ ॥
ਤਾ ਕੀਆ ਗਲਾ ਕਥੀਆ ਨ ਜਾਹਿ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਕਹੈ ਪਿਛੈ ਪਛੁਤਾਇ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਘੜੀਐ ਸੁਰਤਿ ਮਤਿ ਮਨਿ ਬੁਧਿ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਘੜੀਐ ਸੁਰਾ ਸਿਧਾ ਕੀ ਸੁਧਿ ॥੩੬॥
transliteration:
Gi-aan Khand meh gi-aan parchand.
Tithai Naad binod kod anand.
Saram Khand kee baanee roop.
Tithai ghaarhat gharhee-ai bahut anoop.
Taa kee-aa galaa kathee-aa na jaahi.
Je ko kahai pichhai pachhutaa-e.
Tithai gharhee-ai surat mat man budh.
Tithai gharhee-ai suraa sidhaa kee sudh. ||36||
translation:
In the Realm of Knowledge, spiritual wisdom is supreme.
There, the Divine Sound, sights of wonder, and millions of joys and bliss abound.
The Realm of Humility and Effort has a beautiful form (characterized by divine grace).
There, the most wonderfully beautiful spiritual forms are fashioned.
The things of that Realm cannot be described.
Whoever tries to describe them will later regret it.
There, awareness, intellect, understanding, and wisdom are fashioned.
There, the consciousness of the spiritual heroes and Siddhas is fashioned. ||36||
explanation: This pauri continues the description of **'Giaan Khand' (Realm of Knowledge)** and introduces **'Saram Khand' (Realm of Humility/Effort)**. In **Giaan Khand**, spiritual wisdom is paramount, accompanied by divine melodies ('Naad'), joyous spectacles, and immense bliss. The pauri then shifts to **'Saram Khand'**, which is characterized by a beautiful form ('baanee roop') and where uniquely beautiful spiritual forms are fashioned. The nature of this realm is **ineffable ('kathee-aa na jaahi')**, and attempts to describe it are futile. Crucially, in **Saram Khand**, the seeker's **awareness ('surat'), intellect ('mat'), mind ('man'), and wisdom ('budh') are refined and shaped**. It's also where the consciousness of spiritual heroes and perfected beings is developed. This suggests a stage of intense spiritual discipline and inner transformation where the seeker's faculties are divinely molded.

pauri_punjabi:
ਕਰਮ ਖੰਡ ਕੀ ਬਾਣੀ ਜੋਰੁ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਹੋਰੁ ਨ ਕੋਈ ਹੋਰੁ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਜੋਧ ਮਹਾਬਲ ਸੂਰ ॥
ਤਿਨ ਮਹਿ ਰਾਮੁ ਰਹਿਆ ਭਰਪੂਰ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਸੀਤੋ ਸੀਤਾ ਮਹਿਮਾ ਮਾਹਿ ॥
ਤਾ ਕੇ ਰੂਪ ਨ ਕਥਨੇ ਜਾਹਿ ॥
ਨਾ ਓਹਿ ਮਰਹਿ ਨ ਠਾਗੇ ਜਾਹਿ ॥
ਜਿਨ ਕੈ ਰਾਮੁ ਵਸੈ ਮਨ ਮਾਹਿ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਭਗਤ ਵਸਹਿ ਕੇ ਲੋਅ ॥
ਕਰਹਿ ਅਨੰਦੁ ਸਚਾ ਮਨਿ ਸੋਇ ॥
ਸਚ ਖੰਡਿ ਵਸੈ ਨਿਰੰਕਾਰੁ ॥
ਕਰਿ ਕਰਿ ਵੇਖੈ ਨਦਰਿ ਨਿਹਾਲ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਖੰਡ ਮੰਡਲ ਵਰਭੰਡ ॥
ਜੇ ਕੋ ਕਥੈ ਤ ਅੰਤੁ ਨ ਅੰਤੁ ॥
ਤਿਥੈ ਲੋਅ ਲੋਅ ਆਕਾਰ ॥
ਜਿਵ ਜਿਵ ਹੁਕਮੁ ਤਿਵੈ ਤਿਵ ਕਾਰ ॥
ਵੇਖੈ ਵਿਗਸੈ ਕਰਿ ਵੀਚਾਰੁ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਕਥਨਾ ਕਰੜਾ ਸਾਰੁ ॥੩੭॥
transliteration:
Karam Khand kee baanee jor.
Tithai hor na ko-ee hor.
Tithai jodh mahaabal soor.
Tin meh Raam rahi-aa bharpoor.
Tithai seeto seetaa mahimaa maahi.
Taa ke roop na kathne jaahi.
Na oh mareh na thhaage jaahi.
Jin kai Raam vasai man maahi.
Tithai bhagat vaseh ke lo-a.
Karahi anand sachaa man so-e.
Sach Khand vasai Nirankaar.
Kar kar vekhai nadar nihaal.
Tithai khand mandal varbhand.
Je ko kathai ta ant na ant.
Tithai lo-a lo-a aakaar.
Jiv jiv hukam tivai tiv kaar.
Vekhai vigsai kar veechaar.
Naanak kathnaa karh-raa saar. ||37||
translation:
The Realm of Grace (Karam Khand) is dominated by divine power.
No one else can compare with those there.
There live the mighty warriors and supreme heroes.
Within them, the Lord is fully pervasive.
There, they are imbued with the glory of God, soaked in His praise.
Their forms cannot be described.
They do not die, nor are they cheated.
Because the Lord abides within their minds.
There, countless devotees reside.
They experience true joy, for the True One is in their minds.
In the Realm of Truth (Sach Khand) resides the Formless Lord.
He creates, and beholds, and is overjoyed with His Glance of Grace.
There are the continents, worlds, and universes.
If anyone were to describe them, there would be no end to their ends.
There are worlds upon worlds, and forms upon forms.
As is His Command, so is His creative act.
He watches over all, and is immensely pleased, reflecting on His creation.
O Nanak, this description is as hard as steel. ||37||
explanation: This pauri describes **'Karam Khand' (Realm of Grace/Divine Power)** and then transitions into **'Sach Khand' (Realm of Truth)**, the ultimate spiritual abode. In **Karam Khand**, the prevailing force is God's power. Those who reach here are mighty spiritual warriors, completely filled with God's presence. They are eternally absorbed in His glory, their forms beyond description. They are immortal and cannot be deceived because God resides within their minds. Countless devotees live here, experiencing true bliss with God in their hearts. The pauri then ascends to **'Sach Khand'**, the dwelling place of the **Formless Lord ('Nirankar')**. Here, God creates and joyfully oversees His creation with His graceful glance. This realm contains infinite worlds and universes, and their description is endless. All creation operates purely by God's **Command ('Hukam')**. He watches over it, is pleased, and reflects upon it. Guru Nanak concludes by stating that describing this ultimate reality is an incredibly difficult, 'hard as steel', task, emphasizing its transcendental nature.

pauri_punjabi:
ਜਤੁ ਪਾਹਾਰਾ ਧੀਰਜੁ ਸੁਨਿਆਰੁ ॥
ਅਹਰਣਿ ਮਤਿ ਵੇਦੁ ਹਥੀਆਰੁ ॥
ਭਉ ਖਲਾ ਅਗਨਿ ਤਪ ਤਾਉ ॥
ਭਾਂਡਾ ਭਾਉ ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤੁ ਤਿਤੁ ਢਾਲਿ ॥
ਘੜੀਐ ਸਬਦੁ ਸਚੀ ਟਕਸਾਲ ॥
ਜਿਨ ਕਉ ਨਦਰਿ ਕਰਮੁ ਤਿਨ ਕਾਰ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਨਦਰੀ ਨਦਰਿ ਨਿਹਾਲ ॥੩੮॥
transliteration:
Jat paahaaraa dheeraj suni-aar.
Aharn mat ved hathee-aar.
Bha-o khalaa agan tap taa-o.
Bhaandaa bhaa-o amrit tit dhaal.
Gharhee-ai Sabad Sachee Taksaal.
Jin ka-o nadar karam tin kaar.
Naanak nadaree nadar nihaal. ||38||
translation:
Let self-control be the goldsmith's forge, and patience the goldsmith.
Let understanding be the anvil, and spiritual wisdom the tools.
Let the Fear of God be the bellows, and austere discipline the fire.
Let love be the crucible, and in it, melt the Nectar (of the Name).
In this True Mint, the Shabad (Divine Word) is fashioned.
Those who are blessed with His Grace and compassion, perform this spiritual practice.
O Nanak, by His Gracious Glance, one is made happy and blessed. ||38||
explanation: This is the final pauri of Japji Sahib, often considered the **conclusion of the spiritual methodology**. It uses the metaphor of a **goldsmith's mint** to describe the process of forging the **Divine Word (Shabad)** within oneself. **Self-control ('jat')** is the forge, **patience ('dheeraj')** the goldsmith, **understanding ('mat')** the anvil, and **spiritual wisdom ('ved')** the tools. **Fear of God ('Bha-o')** becomes the bellows (which fuels the fire), and **austere discipline ('tap taa-o')** is the fire itself. The **crucible ('bhaandaa')** is divine **love ('bhaa-o')**, where the **Nectar of the Naam ('Amrit')** is melted. Through this rigorous spiritual process, the **'Shabad' (Divine Word)** is fashioned in the **'Sachee Taksaal' (True Mint)**. The pauri concludes by stating that this profound spiritual work is undertaken only by those who receive **God's Grace ('Nadar') and compassion ('karam')**. Ultimately, it is through **God's benevolent glance ('Nadaree Nadar Nihaal')** that one attains supreme bliss and fulfillment. This pauri summarizes the path of spiritual discipline leading to the internalization of the Divine Word and ultimate union with God, all made possible by His Grace.

pauri_punjabi:
ਪਵਣੁ ਗੁਰੂ ਪਾਣੀ ਪਿਤਾ ਮਾਤਾ ਧਰਤਿ ਮਹਤੁ ॥
ਦਿਵਸੁ ਰਾਤਿ ਦੁਇ ਦਾਈ ਦਾਇਆ ਖੇਲੈ ਸਗਲ ਜਗਤੁ ॥
ਚੰਗਿਆਈਆ ਬੁਰਿਆਈਆ ਵਾਚੈ ਧਰਮੁ ਹਦੂਰਿ ॥
ਕਰਮੀ ਆਪੋ ਆਪਣੀ ਕੇ ਨੇੜੈ ਕੇ ਦੂਰਿ ॥
ਜਿਨੀ ਨਾਮੁ ਧਿਆਇਆ ਗਏ ਮਸਕਤਿ ਘਾਲਿ ॥
ਨਾਨਕ ਤੇ ਮੁਖ ਉਜਲੇ ਕੇਤੀ ਛੁਟੀ ਨਾਲਿ ॥੧॥
transliteration:
Pavan Guru Paanee Pitaa Maataa Dharat Mahat.
Divas raat du-e daa-ee daa-i-aa khelai sagal jagat.
Changiaa-ee-aa buri-aa-ee-aa vaachai Dharam Hadoor.
Karmee aapo aapnee ke nerhai ke door.
Jinee Naam dhi-aa-i-aa ga-e maskat ghaal.
Naanak te mukh ujle ketee chhutee naal. ||1||
translation:
Air is the Guru, Water the Father, and the great Earth the Mother.
Day and night are the two nurses, male and female, in whose lap all the world plays.
Righteousness and sin are judged by the Judge of Dharma in His presence.
By their own actions, some are drawn closer, and some are driven farther away.
Those who meditated on the Naam (Name of God), their toil is accomplished.
O Nanak, their faces are radiant, and many others are saved along with them. ||1||
explanation: This **Salok (epilogue/summary)** encapsulates the essence of Japji Sahib. It personifies natural elements as fundamental guides and providers: **Air as the Guru (life-giver/teacher)**, **Water as the Father (source of life)**, and the **Earth as the Great Mother (sustainer)**. Day and night are depicted as the **two nurses** in whose lap all humanity plays. It emphasizes that **all actions, good or bad, are ultimately judged by the Judge of Dharma (Righteousness)** in God's presence, leading to consequences that either bring one closer to or farther from the Divine. The Salok concludes with the ultimate reward: **those who meditate on the Naam (Name of God)** successfully complete their spiritual journey ('maskat ghaal'), their faces shine with divine grace, and their liberation becomes a means for **many others to be saved along with them**. This highlights the profound impact of individual spiritual devotion on the collective and underscores the central message of Naam Simran (meditation on the Name) as the path to liberation.
